{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:56:10Z","duplicateGroupId":"29396015612","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"UNITED STATES; HAWAII, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"88"}],"wordCount":"130","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396059301&p=2kx&v=1&x=vstNgwUqr2F3mAEQF6p7Qg","id":"29396059301","content":"Noah Allen scored a career-high 34 points and grabbed eight rebounds to help Hawaii roll past UC Santa Barbara 78-56 on Saturday night. \n\nAllen, a UCLA graduate transfer, made 11 of 14 from the field, 3 of 5 from 3-point range and all nine of his free throws for the Rainbow Warriors (9-11, 3-4 Big West). \n\nHawaii pulled away with a 12-0 run in the middle of the second half and led by more than 20 points for most of the final 10 minutes. \n\nThe Gauchos (3-16, 1-6) never led after the first seven minutes but stayed close until a 2-for-23 shooting drought that spanned both halves and lasted until Tide Osifeso's 3-pointer with 6:17 left made it 63-44. \n\nThe Bows had a 39-27 rebounding edge and shot 49.1 percent from the field compared to 28.6 by the Gauchos. \n\nMax Heidegger had 10 points to lead UC Santa Barbara.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Sports: latest","group":"Sports"},{"name":"Sports: latest scores","group":"Sports"}],"title":"Noah Allen scores career-high 34, Hawaii beats UCSB 78-56","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Miami-Dade","zipCode":"33172","state":"Florida","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Miami","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"2","name":"Miami Herald","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169657045","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"833"},"name":"Miami Herald","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Sports","Consumer"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.miamiherald.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695201322523","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:56:10Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:05:49Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:05:49Z","duplicateGroupId":"29396059308","companies":[{"symbol":"031860","primary":true,"name":"NSN Co Ltd","contentCount":1,"exchange":"KRX","titleCount":0,"isin":"KR7031860000"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"LAWYERS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"ADMISSION TO PRACTICE LAW","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"LICENSES & PERMITS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"SUPREME COURTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"PETITIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"93"},{"name":"LAW ENFORCEMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"76"},{"name":"LEGAL ETHICS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"CRIMINAL OFFENSES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"76"},{"name":"UNITED STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; NORTH DAKOTA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"94"}],"wordCount":"1991","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396059308&p=2kx&v=1&x=RbcLo32Xu-yzAMgEmhZ4YA","id":"29396059308","content":"Supreme Court of North Dakota. No. 20160436      Decided: January 18, 2017   \n[¶\u20091] On December 14, 2016, eight North Dakota licensed lawyers and two lawyers licensed in another state but temporarily licensed in North Dakota filed a petition for an order allowing non-North Dakota licensed lawyers to represent criminal defendants who have been charged as a result of protest activities connected to the Dakota Access Pipeline. The petitioners request that North Dakota's process for admission of lawyers licensed in another state be significantly changed. \n \n[¶\u20092] The petitioners allege the Fifth, Sixth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution, as well as Article I, § 12 of the North Dakota Constitution, require that North Dakota admit out-of-state lawyers in temporary practice to adequately handle criminal charges stemming from protest activities which they claim overwhelm the North Dakota bar's ability to adequately represent all defendants. The petitioners request that this Court amend our Admission to Practice Rules. \n \n[¶\u20093] The Court established a comment period ending 4 p.m., Friday, December 30, 2016. We received more than 16,000 comments supporting or opposing the petition. Many comments reviewed in favor of the petition give the impression that out-of-state lawyers are not allowed to practice in this state. Others suggest the number of lawyers admitted to practice law in North Dakota is inadequate to handle all of the criminal cases that have arisen out of the protests of the Dakota Access Pipeline. The bulk of the comments appeared to be generated by social media and commented on the merits of the charges filed, the actions of law enforcement and prosecuting lawyers, the placement of or need for the pipeline or the protests in general. These comments are extraneous and unhelpful to resolving the issues raised in the petition. Also beyond the scope of our consideration is modification of rules regulating the permanent admission and licensure of those seeking to become North Dakota lawyers. \n \n[¶\u20094] This Court regulates the admission, licensing and disciplining of lawyers under authority granted by N.D. Const. art. VI, § 3. This constitutional responsibility is carried out in our rule-making authority. The Court's current rules do not prevent out-of-state licensed lawyers from temporarily practicing law in North Dakota. Rather, lawyers licensed in another state are allowed to practice law in North Dakota by filing a motion with the district court in which a case is pending, attesting to their admission, licensing and discipline information, associating with a lawyer who is licensed in North Dakota and paying an annual fee. N.D. Admission to Practice R. 3(A). While the North Dakota lawyer's name must be included on all pleadings, that lawyer's in-person appearance can be excused by the district judge presiding in the matter. This pro hac vice process under Rule 3(A) of the Admission to Practice Rules is available now and is regularly used by many clients and lawyers in both criminal and civil cases. \n \n[¶\u20095] North Dakota also allows for full admission by application of experienced lawyers. See N.D. Admission to Practice R. 7. We are among the first states allowing out-of-state lawyers to temporarily practice law in North Dakota while their application for full admission is pending. See N.D. Admission to Practice R. 6.1. Two out-of-state lawyers who signed the petition pending before this Court are right now authorized to practice law in North Dakota under this rule. That is a privilege their resident state of licensure does not grant to North Dakota's or other states' lawyers. \n \n[¶\u20096] Rule 3.1 of the Admission to Practice Rules also authorizes the practice of law in civil matters for lawyers volunteering with approved legal services organizations. Rule 3.2 of the Admission to Practice Rules authorizes the provision of legal services following a determination of a major disaster. These rules, as well as Rule 3 of the Admission to Practice Rules, were reviewed for guidance in light of the petition and the comments received. \n \n[¶\u20097] The petitioners question North Dakota's requirement that lawyers not licensed in North Dakota who seek pro hac vice admission associate with a licensed North Dakota lawyer. Requiring an associate lawyer in the state where a case is venued is common throughout the United States. See COMPARISON OF ABA MODEL RULE FOR PRO HAC VICE ADMISSION WITH STATE VERSIONS, available at http://www.americanbar.org/content/dam/aba/administrative/professional_responsibility/prohac_admin_comp.authcheckdam.pdf (last visited Jan. 12, 2017). Requiring an associate lawyer is an important and legitimate state interest to protect the public from unlicensed lawyers who often are unfamiliar with state-specific court rules, procedures and laws. \n \n[¶\u20098] The petitioners and many comments suggest an emergency exists which requires amending North Dakota's rules to allow a pro hac vice application and temporary admission process similar to the United States District Court for the District of North Dakota. They suggest that, among other things, the federal process does not require an associate lawyer, and that eliminating the need for an associate lawyer will alleviate the perceived shortage of criminal defense counsel. The federal courts do not require an associate lawyer for a number of reasons, including that the same federal rules of procedure apply nationwide and the cases usually are decided according to federal law. The same cannot be said of our state rules, statutes and judicial rulings. \n \n[¶\u20099] We further reject as unsupported by evidence the suggestion that the South Central Judicial District is not currently handling the protest-related criminal cases in a timely manner due to unavailability of counsel. We have been provided with no evidence that a specific defendant has been denied counsel due to the unavailability of criminal defense or pro hac vice associate lawyers licensed in North Dakota. To the contrary, comments received in this process from the North Dakota Commission on Legal Counsel for Indigents state that lawyers have been assigned in \u201call cases in which someone has been found eligible to have indigent defense services provided by the Commission.\u201d The Commission provided the following information: \n \n\u2022\u2009553 court cases were filed in district court in the South Central Judicial District resulting from Dakota Access Pipeline protests as of December 19, 2016; \n \n\u2022\u2009The Commission made 291 case assignments, constituting approximately 53 percent of the protest-related court cases; \n \n\u2022\u2009The Commission assigned an attorney in all cases in which a defendant is eligible to receive indigent defense services; \n \n\u2022\u2009The Commission has made case assignments to 81 attorneys; \n \n\u2022\u2009The 81 assigned attorneys are from commission offices throughout North Dakota, from contract lawyers throughout North Dakota, and from \u201c45 hourly/conflict contractors from other districts [in North Dakota] and NW Minnesota;\u201d and \n \n\u2022\u2009A large number of arrests and charges occurred on single days. Those circumstances required assignment of different counsel for each defendant. For one of those days, 71 different attorneys were needed and assignments have been made. \n \nReview of our case management system records shows that the Indigent Defense Commission has continued from mid-December to make indigent defense case assignments. The South Central Judicial District's comment filed in this matter states that all qualifying protest-related indigent defendants have been provided counsel. \n \n[¶\u200910] The petition can be read as requesting, and some filing comments have suggested, that this Court utilize provisions of N.D. Sup. Ct. Admin. R. 57 and declare a judicial emergency. By its terms, that rule was adopted to address \u201can emergency or natural disaster [that] substantially endangers or infringes upon the normal functioning of the judicial system, the ability of persons to avail themselves of the judicial system, the ability of litigants or others to have access to the courts, or to meet schedules or deadlines imposed by court order or rule, statute, or administrative rule.\u201d Id. at § 1. We are not willing to categorize the protests of the Dakota Access Pipeline and charges stemming from them as either a natural disaster or a judicial emergency. Normal judicial processes and the requested deficiency appropriations for the North Dakota Judicial System and the North Dakota Commission on Legal Counsel for Indigents are expected to protect each criminal defendant's constitutional rights. We nevertheless recognize the potential for delay or inconvenience for litigants due to the relatively large number of arrests and finite resources to handle the judicial proceedings related to those arrests. \n \n[¶\u200911] Due to the significant increased caseload of the South Central Judicial District as a result of criminal charges stemming from the pipeline protests, a surrogate judge has been assigned to the district to assist the workload. Due to this same increased caseload, this Court in its discretion will allow temporary streamlining of our procedures for temporary admission of lawyers to provide pro bono services. \n \n[¶\u200912] In criminal cases pending in the South Central Judicial District arising from arrests made during the protests of the Dakota Access Pipeline between August 1, 2016 and until further order of this Court, a lawyer authorized to practice law in another state, and not disbarred, suspended or otherwise restricted from practice in any jurisdiction, may provide legal services in North Dakota on a temporary basis. The legal services must be provided on a pro bono basis, without payment or the expectation of payment of a fee. This Order does not prohibit a lawyer providing legal services under authority of this Order from being reimbursed from non-governmental funds for actual expenses incurred while rendering services under this Order. The following requirements, processes and procedures shall apply: \n \n1)\u2003The lawyer seeking pro hac vice admission must complete a form available through the Clerk of the Supreme Court and file it with the North Dakota State Board of Law Examiners; \n \n2)\u2003The lawyer seeking pro hac vice admission must file the above-referenced form with a certificate from his or her resident state licensing authority certifying the lawyer is admitted, currently licensed, eligible to practice and in good standing; \n \n3)\u2003The lawyer seeking pro hac vice admission must associate with a licensed North Dakota lawyer as required under N.D. Admission Prac. R. 3. We excuse the requirement that the North Dakota associate lawyer appear in-person and remain in court for all proceedings unless the district judge presiding in the case enters an order, based on a case-specific reason, requiring the presence of the North Dakota associate lawyer; \n \n4)\u2003The pro hac vice filing fee is waived; \n \n5)\u2003Upon receipt of the completed form and required materials, the North Dakota State Board of Law Examiners will provide the lawyer seeking pro hac vice admission an identification number that must be included on all pleadings filed with any court regarding these matters; \n \n6)\u2003Each business day the Clerk of the Supreme Court shall provide the Court Administrator for the South Central Judicial District with a listing of all lawyers who have been granted pro hac vice admission as provided in this Order; \n \n7)\u2003Lawyers admitted pro hac vice must access the North Dakota Odyssey electronic case management system through the associate lawyer unless the associate lawyer does not subscribe to North Dakota's Odyssey case management system. If the associate lawyer does not subscribe to Odyssey case management system, the lawyer admitted pro hac vice may e-mail filings to the clerk of court; \n \n8)\u2003The lawyer admitted pro hac vice under this Order is not by virtue of that admission limited in the number of appearances or representations he or she can make regarding these matters; \n \n9)\u2003The lawyer admitted pro hac vice under this Order must remain licensed and in good standing in the lawyer's state of licensure, and must verify in writing to the North Dakota State Board of Law Examiners no later than January 5, 2018, their licensure status and provide a listing of pending cases for which they are acting under this Order; and \n \n10)\u2003Any allegations of misconduct by a lawyer admitted pro hac vice under this Order that is reported to the Disciplinary Board of North Dakota will be provided to the lawyer's state of licensure, and may be grounds for revocation of pro hac vice admission under this Order. \n \n[¶\u200913] We encourage the State Bar Association of North Dakota, the North Dakota Association for Justice and Legal Services of North Dakota to assist in locating North Dakota licensed lawyers to serve as associate lawyers. \n \n[¶\u200914] Any other remedies requested by the petitioners are denied at this time. \n \n[¶\u200915] This Order remains in effect until further order of the Court. \n \nPer Curiam. \n \n[¶\u200916] Gerald W. VandeWalle, C.J. Carol Ronning Kapsner Lisa Fair McEvers Daniel J. Crothers Jerod E. {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T00:00:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29392249353","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"EXECUTIVES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"50"},{"name":"SCULPTURE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"ADOLESCENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"67"},{"name":"BRITISH ROYALTY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"74"},{"name":"VISUAL ARTISTS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"73"},{"name":"THIS DAY IN HISTORY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"ANNIVERSARIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"UNITED KINGDOM","domains":["GEO"],"score":"57"},{"name":"PRINCESS DIANA","domains":["PEO"],"score":"58"},{"name":"PRINCE WILLIAM","domains":["PEO"],"score":"58"},{"name":"PRINCE HARRY","domains":["PEO"],"score":"78"},{"name":"PRINCE GEORGE OF CAMBRIDGE","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"391","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396059838&p=2kx&v=1&x=fe2haQJnX-8tmzEKItK3zw","id":"29396059838","content":"Prince William and Prince Harry will mark the 20th anniversary of Princess Diana\u2019s death by commissioning a statue of their mother. \n \nIn a joint statement the two Princes said: It has been 20 years since our mother\u2019s death and the time is right to recognise her positive impact in the UK and around the world with a permanent statue. \n \nOur mother touched so many lives. We hope the statue will help all those who visit Kensington Palace to reflect on her life and her legacy. \n \nThe statue of the Princess will be placed in a public part of Kensington Palace gardens, Diana\u2019s former home. \n \nThe Princes have asked a small committee to help them come up with a design and choose a sculptor. \n \nThe committee includes Diana\u2019s sister, Lady Sarah McCorquodale, Julia Samuel, a godparent of Prince George who was a close friend of the Princess, and will be chaired by Jamie Lowther-Pinkerton, their former principal private secretary. \n \nIt is hoped the statue will be unveiled later this year. \n \nWilliam was 15 years old and Harry just 12 when their mother Diana was killed in a car crash in Paris on 31 August 1997. It was not clear until now how they would mark the 20th anniversary. \n \nOther organisations have announced plans to remember her. \n \nThe Historic Royal Palaces are displaying an exhibition of her clothes and dresses at Kensington Palace from February, tracing the evolution of her style. \n \nA specially designed white garden will also be planted in the grounds of the palace this spring and summer. \n \nThe Diana Award, the only charity that bears the name of Diana, Princess of Wales, has launched their legacy awards celebrating children and teenagers who have transformed the lives of others. \n \nChief executive Tessy Ojo said: Twenty years ago most of the young people we work with were not here, but one of the ways we talk to them about the princess is through her work, her work in community, her kindness, how she reached out. \n \nI think it\u2019s important to keep Diana\u2019s legacy alive because she really changed society, she changed how we interact with various things {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T00:00:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395375060","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"HISTORY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"COINS & COINAGE","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"91"},{"name":"BRITISH MONARCHS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"ANCIENT HISTORY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"MUSEUMS & GALLERIES","domains":["IND"],"score":"73"},{"name":"ENGLAND","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"},{"name":"OXFORD, ENGLAND; ENGLAND","domains":["GEO"],"score":"77"}],"wordCount":"408","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396059844&p=2kx&v=1&x=P43piqqUcErdtaglfbaNag","id":"29396059844","content":"Historians say an entire chapter of the Anglo-Saxon period will have to be re-written after a metal detectorist found a huge hoard of coins in a field. \n \nJames Mather made the discovery of 200 complete silver coins, seven items of jewellery and 15 silver ingots in a field near Watlington in Oxfordshire in October 2015. Its full significance has now become apparent. \n \nThe find contained a mixture of extremely rare Anglo-Saxon coins and Viking silver, which provides a clearer understanding of the relationship between Alfred the Great, who ruled Wessex and his less well-known contemporary Ceolwulf II of Mercia. \n \nSome of the coins were minted with a \u2018Two Emperors\u2019 design, borrowed from the Romans, which shows that the currency was used in both ancient kingdoms. \n \nThis is an extraordinary find, one which re-writes Anglo-Saxon history, Xa Sturgis, director of the Ashmolean Museum in Oxford, which now houses the coins, told Sky News. \n \nThe keeper of the coin room here came running up the stairs to tell me. The more they were excavated the more it became obvious how significant they are. These coins point to some sort of an alliance in the 870s between Alfred and Ceolwulf. \n \nWhile Alfred is often described as the king who founded England, uniting Mercia and Wessex, very little is known of his rival Ceolwulf. \n \nThese coins prove that there was a very real alliance between the two men at that time, added Julian Baker, coin curator at the Ashmolean. \n \nThat alliance hasn\u2019t survived in the historical record until now. Alfred manipulated history to put himself in a better light. To date, history has overemphasised Alfred\u2019s record and almost completely neglected Ceolwulf. \n \nWe can start re-writing that decade now, courtesy of the Watlington hoard. \n \nThe Ashmolean has until Monday, 31 January, to raise £1.35m to keep the coins and Viking silver in Oxfordshire and they are extremely close to that figure now. \n \nMore than 500 people in the local area have donated to the fund set up to raise the cash. \n \nMr Sturgis added: Alfred is the only king in the history of England described as \u2018great\u2019. But these coins show that in the 870s he needed Ceolwulf. It\u2019s incredible that we know so little about him and Alfred dominates everything. It\u2019s like he obliterated Ceolwulf. \n \nThe Watlington Hoard, as it is now known, is on public display at the Ashmolean as historians begin the process of re-assessing that period of Anglo-Saxon history. \n \n(c) Sky News 2017: Comments  \ncomments","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[],"title":"Coins discovery \u2018will re-write\u2019 Anglo-Saxon history","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Europe","subregion":"Northern Europe","county":"Isle of Wight","zipCode":"PO30","state":"England","countryCode":"GB","zipArea":"Isle of Wight","country":"United Kingdom"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Isle of Wight Radio","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"172637663","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"10"},"name":"Isle of Wight Radio","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.iwradio.co.uk"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695201335616","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T00:00:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:05:56Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://iwradio.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/sites/3/2017/01/91ee536f8109128c59083573d526911b227c379609fe0763c27cfa771921a048_3879920.jpeg"}],"video":[]}}

NEW SOUTH WALES, AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"90"},{"name":"AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"SYDNEY, AUSTRALIA; AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"91"}],"wordCount":"492","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396059758&p=2kx&v=1&x=rB807ydUgYgPwHAFUzbWrw","id":"29396059758","content":"School students across NSW will sweat through their first days back at school, with scorching temperatures tipped to reach 42 degrees in Penrith and Richmond on Monday. \n\nThe extreme heat will continue on Monday night through to Tuesday before an afternoon cool change brings some relief.\n\n\"It's going to be a hot start to the school year,\" Bureau of Meteorology duty forecaster Rob Taggart said. \"Dropping off the kids, it's going to feel pretty warm and humid.\"\n\nWhile a sea breeze will keep Sydney's predicted maximum to a comparatively mild 32 degrees on Monday, Richmond is poised to break an all-time record with a sixth January day above 40 degrees.\n\nThere will be no relief on Monday night with temperatures in the west still hovering around or even above 30 degrees at midnight, Mr Taggart said. \n\nCompounding the heat is a \"widespread severe fire danger\" in southern NSW and far western NSW on Monday, with a \"very high fire danger\" for Sydney and the Hunter region, Mr Taggart said. \n\nIn central and south-western parts of state, last year's floods have . \"Grass fuel loads are pretty high because of all that rainfall,\" Mr Taggart said. \"The grass is pretty brown and there's a lot of it. It's ready and waiting to go.\"\n\nThe state's maximum temperature is expected in Wilcannia, with a blistering top of 46 degrees. \n\nThe three-day heatwave forecast for Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday. Photo: Bureau of Meteorology\n\nIf this January has seemed hotter and drier than usual, that's because it has been - especially at night. \n\nMaximum daytime temperatures in Sydney last January averaged 27.4 degrees. This January has so far averaged 29.1 degrees, which should rise with two more hot days to end the month. \n\nMeanwhile, Sydney has smashed the previous record for hot nights in January, with four nights (so far) staying above 24 degrees. The previous record was two. \n\nSydney is on track to break the record for the number of summer days above 35 degrees, with just two more needed to break the all-time record\n\nMr Taggart said this January has been \"almost certainly one of the hottest on record\".\n\nAnd the heat won't end this week. Next weekend is forecast to again hit 40 degrees, Mr Taggart said, as the Bureau forecasts a \"hotter than average\" February with hot conditions pushing into March. \n\nJanuary is also likely to end with less than half the month's average rainfall. So far the city has had 48.8mm, much lower than the average of 102.5mm.\n\nIt's also significantly less than last year when Sydney received 249.8mm during January.\n\nElsewhere in the state, Moree is in the middle of a remarkable hot streak, with the town sweltering through 34 consecutive days above 35 degrees. Mr Taggart expects that to stretch to 41 days based on current forecasts, close to the state record. \n\n\"The forecast for the next seven days is pretty horrific,\" Mr Taggart said. \"That heat is completely unrelenting.\"\n\n\"The forecast seems bad for Richmond and Sydney, but it's nothing compared to Moree.\"","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Josh Dye"},"topics":[{"name":"Weather news","group":"Science"},{"name":"Society news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Education news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Oceania latest","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Australia news","group":"Regional"}],"title":"NSW weather: Heatwave, severe fire danger as students return to school","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Oceania","subregion":"Australia and New Zealand","zipCode":"6004","state":"Western Australia","countryCode":"AU","zipArea":"East Perth","country":"Australia"},"editorialRank":"2","name":"WA Today","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169588399","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"27"},"name":"WA Today","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Environment","Society","Standard"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.watoday.com.au","publisher":"Fairfax Media"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695201337063","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:59:13Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:05:55Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:00:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395880552","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"CHRISTMAS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"HOLIDAYS & OBSERVANCES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"SOCCER","domains":["SUB"],"score":"74"},{"name":"SPORTS & RECREATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"88"},{"name":"SOUTH AMERICA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"77"},{"name":"ENGLAND","domains":["GEO"],"score":"88"},{"name":"NETHERLANDS","domains":["GEO"],"score":"77"},{"name":"LONDON, ENGLAND","domains":["GEO"],"score":"58"},{"name":"ARGENTINA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"95"},{"name":"GERMANY","domains":["GEO"],"score":"73"},{"name":"BUENOS AIRES, ARGENTINA; ARGENTINA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"EUROPE","domains":["GEO"],"score":"90"}],"wordCount":"1271","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396059910&p=2kx&v=1&x=4fHkjVXmIqjUj5ANDEOocw","id":"29396059910","content":"Chargrilled steaks, chicken and sausages. Not your typical festive meal in England but on a street in the leafy Cheshire suburbs, it was the way Ramiro Funes Mori and his friends celebrated the recent holiday season. \nThe 25-year-old is 7,000 miles away from his home city in Argentina, but he still remains true to his traditions. He\u2019s South American and proud. \n\n\u201cOn Christmas Eve we went to Sergio Romero\u2019s and then on New Year\u2019s Eve we were at Sergio Aguero\u2019s house,\u201d he explains. \u201cWe had a Christmas barbecue with all the lads. In Argentina, we like to eat meat a lot!\u201d \n\nThose \u2018lads\u2019, as Funes puts it, are his compatriots, international teammates affiliated to various Premier League clubs across the region. There is an Argentinian hub in the north-west and, naturally, they all stick together. \n\n\u201cWe are all nearby and close to each other - Nicolas Otamendi lives two doors down from me,\u201d Funes adds. \u201cIt was good for all our families to spend time together and celebrate. It felt like being at home - we played music, danced and enjoyed Christmas. All the kids played, we ate and had a fun time.\u201d \nThe defender relaxes into his chair at USM Finch Farm. He is happy to talk about his background and heritage, a welcome change from conversation surrounding on-the-pitch matters. \n\n\u201cArgentina is a nice country, the place I was born,\u201d he continues. \u201cWarm climate, sunny with nice weather. There\u2019s good food, lots of tradition and fun to visit if you are from overseas. It is hard when you have to come to another country but it\u2019s what I wanted - I wanted to play in Europe. \n\n\u201cThere are things I miss like friends and family. I actually miss our traditional Argentinian drink! It\u2019s called maté and is made from herbs. You have it with boiling hot water. It\u2019s a drink you share and have whilst you are sat speaking and socialising. Lots of people in Argentina enjoy it. There are some places in London which sell it but I bring it back when I go home.\u201d \n\n\n\nSince his £10m switch to Everton from River Plate in August 2015, Funes has become a mainstay in his national team. Regular call-ups, of course, provide the chance to journey back to his homeland several times a year and, indeed, the flurry of international breaks in the early part of the season meant he was involved in Argentina\u2019s World Cup qualifying fixtures during September, October and November. \n\n\u201cI\u2019m used to the travelling now,\u201d he says. \u201cIt\u2019s a long journey, about 12 to 14 hours and I have to catch a connecting flight in Holland or Germany to get to Buenos Aires. Argentina players based in England, like Marcos Rojo, and others from around Europe will catch the same flights. Yes, it gets tiring but I don\u2019t think of it like that. \n\n\u201cMy family travel with me, too. It\u2019s good because my wife gets to see her relatives and my son can play with his little friends. I sometimes get the chance to see my parents but not always because they live on the other side of the country [in a city called Mendoza]. They have only had the chance to visit England once before, back in March. I showed them around and took them to a nice Argentina restaurant in Liverpool called CAU. I like to go out and try new foods but it has been nice to find a restaurant from home.\u201d \n\nAway from his day-to-day work, Funes Mori enjoys the comfort of spending his spare time venturing out in public places without too much attention. Yes, there will be the occasional autograph to sign and photo to pose for, but it\u2019s a complete contrast to his previous way of life in Buenos Aires. \n\nThe defender was one of River Plate\u2019s highest-profile players, a hero amongst supporters largely thanks to his famous match-winning goal in their \u2019Classico\u2019 win at the home of their cross-city rivals, Boca Juniors, in 2014. His last-minute header was a vital contribution as River reclaimed the domestic title for the first time in five years. \n\n\u201cOver here I feel free,\u201d he explains with honesty. \u201cI like to go to the park with my child and wife. It\u2019s nice to get out because not too many people recognise me. I like to go to the shopping mall, just stroll around and buy things. I\u2019m a humble person. \n\n\u201cIf I walked around Buenos Aires, people would all want pictures. When I go back home to Argentina it\u2019s different because there are a lot of River Plate fans so I hardly go out, maybe just to a restaurant to eat. It\u2019s part of my job and it\u2019s not that I don\u2019t like it, but sometimes it feels a little bit irritating. It\u2019s normal though - when people see someone famous they like to get pictures. I\u2019m playing in the national team and because of that the whole country looks at you.\u201d \n\nThis is where the conversation turns to Lionel Messi. \n\nFunes Mori is sat in the media room at USM Finch Farm holding his mobile phone. Stored away in the contacts list on the device is the number of the Barcelona superstar. He grins, somewhat embarrassingly, at the suggestion that he is good pals with one of the most distinguishable sportsmen on the planet. \n\n\u201cLionel is an uncomplicated person but everything he says or does becomes public,\u201d Funes reveals. \u201cHe goes anywhere and he is recognised. Some of the things he does in training are incredible. I don\u2019t get the chance to speak to him too much because I\u2019m a shy person.\u201d \n\nMessi announced he was turning his back on international football in June in the wake of Argentina\u2019s Copa America final penalty shootout defeat to Chile, before reversing his decision a couple of months later. \n\n\n \n\u201cIt\u2019s great that he came out of retirement because we need him a lot,\u201d continues the defender. \u201cIt\u2019s not just Argentina, football needs him because he is the best player in the world. \n\n\u201cFor the national team, we were disappointed because we wanted to be champions. We did our best to win the cup and, unfortunately, because of penalty kicks we couldn\u2019t do that. That\u2019s how football is. But, for me, the first time playing in a Copa America and reaching the final, it was an unbelievable experience.\u201d \n\nFunes now has 18 senior caps to his name. The standard of his performances have drawn acclaim and, in November, legendary defender Daniel Passarella, the man who skippered Argentina to World Cup glory in 1978, insisted the Everton centre-back should be handed the captain\u2019s armband for his country. \nA huge compliment from one of the most respected figures in the game but one that Funes plays down. \n\n\u201cThere are lots of captains before me; Messi and [Javier] Mascherano,\u201d he declares. \u201cI worked with Passarella at River Plate when he was the president. He was one of the best defenders in the world so to hear that from him is good. I accept his opinion and I really like it but I don\u2019t consider myself as a captain.\u201d \n\nThe interview ends with a glance to the future. Once Funes has realised his ambitions in England, he is resolute in a desire to return to South America to end his professional career at the place it started. \n\n\u201cWhen I go back to River Plate as one of the experienced players, maybe I would like to be the team\u2019s captain,\u201d he states. \u201cI would like to retire in Argentina because I won a lot of important things with River Plate and I think that it would be good to go back there.\u201d","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Sports: EPL - Everton news","group":"Sports Teams"},{"name":"Sports: latest","group":"Sports"},{"name":"Sports: soccer news","group":"Sports"},{"name":"Sports: Premier League news","group":"Sports"}],"title":"Feeling Right At Home","source":{"category":"Consumer","location":{"region":"Europe","subregion":"Northern Europe","countryCode":"GB","country":"United Kingdom"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Everton FC","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169681269","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"99"},"name":"Everton FC","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Consumer","Sports","Soccer"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.evertonfc.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695201340204","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:00:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:05:57Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

Field, has fought a long battle to persuade Sir Philip to pay up. \n \nAn agreement between the tycoon and regulators could leave BHS pensioners continuing to face modest cuts to their benefits, demand for a sum north of £350m. \n \nLesley Titcomb, chief executive of the Pensions Regulator, is also under pressure to hammer out a deal that guarantees payments to more than 20,000 pensioners. \n at £571m but is thought to have increased substantially as ultra-low interest rates have depressed gilt yields. \n \nSir Philip, whose high street empire includes brands such as Top Shop and Dorothy He was quite social on his table that he was sitting at apparently. I think he was just very glad of that and the other few occasions when we would invite him to family parties, Mr Dias said. \n \nMr Dias said they were neighbours from the 1980s until Mr Lytton moved to Pakistan in 2005, without warning. \n \nNeighbours say he was a tube driver, and at one stage perhaps worked as a taxi driver and even a casino croupier. \n \nMr Lytton was found on the morning of 12 December 2015, fully clothed and facing the summit of Indian\u2019s Head, a prominent feature above Dovestone Reservoir on Saddleworth Moor in the Peak District. \n \nPolice discovered he had travelled to the UK from Lahore, Pakistan, two days before his death. \n \nThree train tickets and £130 in cash were found on his body, but he had no wallet, ID or phone. \n \nOn the day before his body was found, he was seen on CCTV pacing outside London\u2019s Ealing Broadway station. He was later seen at London\u2019s Euston station. \n \nHe then travelled by train from London to Manchester, where he entered a pub in Greenfield and asked for directions to the 1,500ft summit. \n \nHe had been warned not to attempt the walk so late in the day but set off anyway. Witnesses saw him on the track at dusk that evening. \n \nFollowing his death, toxicology reports showed Mr Lytton had been killed by strychnine, which is found in rat poison. Police say he poisoned himself. \n \nNumerous theories about his identity were raised as the police investigation continued. \n \nIt wasn\u2019t until a leg implant was traced back to Lahore where the surgery had been carried out and his identity was discovered. \n \nWe\u2019ve found the whole thing very sad, Mr Dias said. I think he was a very lonely person with only a few regular visitors. When he left we have no recollection of him saying goodbye to us. I would go as far to use the word recluse. He would keep himself to himself but was always a very pleasant person. \n \nA full inquest will take place on 14 March. \n http://video.news.sky.com/video/h264/vod/700/2017/01/DIGIDavidLyttonMysteryBodyVT1485665079770700.mp4 \n(c) Sky News 2017: skynews","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Pakistan news","group":"Regional"}],"title":"Man found dead on Saddleworth Moor was \u2018a lonely character\u2019","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Europe","subregion":"Northern Europe","county":"Isle of Wight","zipCode":"PO30","state":"England","countryCode":"GB","zipArea":"Isle of Wight","country":"United Kingdom"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Isle of Wight Radio","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"172637663","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"10"},"name":"Isle of Wight Radio","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.iwradio.co.uk"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["http://video.news.sky.com/video/h264/vod/700/2017/01/DIGIDavidLyttonMysteryBodyVT1485665079770700.mp4"],"sequenceId":"695201340746","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T00:00:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:05:57Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://iwradio.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/sites/3/2017/01/57b8e752d3447a4c87c9b32c274a45032de758ea7e5ea100ec8b76768e731faf_3879965.jpeg"}],"video":[]}}

managed by Dubai-based Central Hotels group, has been awarded Green Key \n   \nGreen-Key \n  AL BARSHA, UAE - Jan. 29, 2017 - PRLog -- First Central Hotel Suites, managed by Dubai-based Central Hotels group, has been awarded Green Key Certification 2016-2017 for its green practices that include a host of environment- friendly energy, water and waste management initiatives. \nGreen Key is a sustainability certification program for hotels and accommodation that was developed by the Foundation for Environment Education. As non-governmental, non-profit and independent program, Green Key is recognized by the World Tourism Organisation and United Nations Environment Program (UNEP), and is the largest global eco-label relating to accommodation. Since 2013, Emirates Green Building Council acts as Green Key National Operator in the United Arab Emirates. \n\nCommenting on the achievement, Wael El Behi, General Manager of First Central Hotel Suites, said, \"We believe in responsible and sustainable practices without compromising on guest comfort, personal service, or value. In line with the commitment to reducing our carbon footprint, we are delighted to receive the Green Key Certification that is recognized worldwide. \n\n\"It is a great environmental initiative that has been instrumental in mobilizing global action on raising awareness about the need to conserve our environment and we are proud to be part of it. We have had an overwhelming response from our staff and guests who are enthusiastically participating and engaging in green initiatives. From conserving water to recycling materials and saving energy, they are keen to assert their green credentials. Our energy efficiency best practices helped us to reduce the energy bill by 4% in 2016 compared to 2015. We are now using LED lights all over the hotel with over 5000 bulbs changed last year to meet Green Key objectives. By changing day to day habits we could all make the world a better place for our future generations\" . \n\nAbout First Central Hotel Suites \n\nFeaturing 524 apartments, equipped with top-notch facilities, First Central Hotel Suites is superbly located in Barsha Heights (TECOM) near Sheikh Zayed Road in close proximity to Dubai Marina, Montgomerie and Emirates Golf Clubs and Mall of the Emirates. We have offered to help them clean out the locker, and possibly make money from some of the items in there, but they never commit. You and your siblings are good children, but it's time for an intervention. Before giving your parents more money, you should all sit down with them and help them to create a budget, taking into account their fixed income and what you children can afford as a supplement. What is the best way to deal with this situation? -- WANTING TO WITHDRAW \n   \nDEAR WANTING: The poor man is probably lonely and looking for human contact. {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:06:04Z","duplicateGroupId":"29396060625","companies":[{"symbol":"065560","primary":true,"name":"Cubes Inc","contentCount":1,"exchange":"KRX","titleCount":0,"isin":"KR7065560005"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"COOKING & ENTERTAINING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"}],"wordCount":"602","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396060625&p=2kx&v=1&x=qLc3UgKADn20uI_BHvx2LQ","id":"29396060625","content":"Rain, rain, go away \u2026 not in my book! I\u2019m loving it. \n   \nNothing makes a home homier than the aroma of homemade bread, add that to a rainy day and I\u2019m in heaven. \n   \nAn old family favorite, one I get frequent requests to repeat, is my mother\u2019s tried-and-true \u201cFrench\u201d bread. Notice the French in quotes. This isn\u2019t an authentic version, just a terrific recipe that can mimic a French taste by playing around with the salt and sugar quantities. \n   \nMy mother, an avid baker, got this from a friend during the 1940s and it has been a staple in my family ever since. I refer to it as her no-need-to-knead bread. \n   \nThis is a multipurpose, basic bread. It\u2019s a soft dough and needs to be baked in a pan. For company, I often double or triple the recipe, divide it into eighths or 12ths, and use miniature pans. That way each diner gets his or her own loaf. \n   \nOne recipe makes four small or two rounded loaves when baked in one-quart Corningware casseroles, which are perfect for rounded, crusty loaves. \n   \nMix up the flours, too. Use part whole wheat or rye \u2014 no more than 1 to 1 1/2 cups \u2014 add some of your sourdough starter during the yeast-softening stage, throw in a handful or two of oatmeal, wheat germ, millet, nuts or sunflower seeds, etc., the possibilities are endless. I\u2019ve tossed in dried herbs, onions and garlic as well as small cubes of cheese, all came out delicious. \n   \nAnd, I repeat, you can\u2019t mess up this recipe as long as you keep the yeast, wet and dry ingredients in the proportions given. \n   \nIt\u2019s great with barbecue, spaghetti, salads and for sandwiches. I\u2019ve never had any left over long enough to try it as French toast, but I\u2019m sure it would work there, too. \n   \nThis recipe is quick to make, but it does require two risings, and depending on how warm your kitchen is, may take anywhere from two to four hours for the first one, then just less than 30 minutes for the second. \n   \nIf I\u2019m making soup, stew, a spot of chili beans or spaghetti, I start this first and by the time everything else is ready, the bread is baked. \n   \nWhether the rain keeps up or not, give your family a treat and bake this soon. \n   \n Get tips on free stuff and fun ideas delivered weekly to your inbox  \n   \nHomemade bread \n   \n1 pkg. quick-acting dry yeast \n   \n2 c. lukewarm water, approximately \n   \n1 Tbsp. sugar \n   \n2 tsp. salt \n   \n4 c. sifted all-purpose flour \n   \nDissolve yeast in 1 cup water. Measure and sift flour with sugar and salt into a large bowl. Stir in softened yeast. Add just enough water to hold dough together. Mix until you have soft, rather sticky dough. Cover with cloth and set bowl in a warm spot in your kitchen but not near direct heat. Let rise until double in size. This takes from 2 to 4 hours depending upon room temperature. When high and spongy, punch down with greased hands and give it a good sound beating. Divide dough into two for large loaves, or four small parts and place each in a well-greased baking dish/pan. Cover again with cloth and let rise until dough reaches top of baking dish. At this point start oven, 400 degrees or moderately hot. Place bread in oven and when crust has started to firm up, spray or brush with olive oil or melted butter, then bake until nicely browned. Remove from oven, let stand a few minutes to cool slightly before taking out of pans. For crusty bread, cool on a rack; for soft crust, wrap warm loaves in a dishtowel until cool.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Consumer durables news","group":"Industry"},{"name":"Opinion latest","group":"Society"}],"title":"Bread in the oven, so let it rain","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Santa Barbara","zipCode":"93455","state":"California","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Santa Maria","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Santa Maria Times","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169671980","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"18"},"name":"Santa Maria Times","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Lifestyle","Consumer"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.santamariatimes.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695201348727","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:06:04Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:06:03Z","duplicateGroupId":"29396060519","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"SOCIAL NETWORKING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"},{"name":"SOCIAL MEDIA","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"LEGISLATIVE BODIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"66"},{"name":"CITIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"50"},{"name":"INTERNET SOCIAL NETWORKING","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"WRITERS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"MOBILE DEVICES","domains":["IND"],"score":"73"},{"name":"CITY GOVERNMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"50"},{"name":"PRIME MINISTERS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"51"},{"name":"UNITED STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"66"}],"wordCount":"257","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396060519&p=2kx&v=1&x=NMKaAIDCaNWFSORvJGlS8A","id":"29396060519","content":"Subscribe today for full access on your desktop, tablet, and mobile device. \n Subscribe Now              Share This Story!  \nLet friends in your social network know what you are reading about \n  Grammar Gremlins: Use quotation marks when inserting nicknames  \nWhat is the proper style for inserting a person\u2019s nickname into his or her written full name? Most stylebooks specify placing the nickname after the forename and enclosing it in quotation marks. \n    Post to Facebook    \nTry Another \n\nAudio CAPTCHA \n\nImage CAPTCHA \n\nHelp \n]]>  \n{#  #} \n  \nCancel Send \n   Sent!  \nA link has been sent to your friend's email address. \n     Posted!  \nA link has been posted to your Facebook feed. \n       \nDon Ferguson, Columnist  3:00 a.m. ET Jan. 29, 2017 \n   Buy Photo  \nDon K. Ferguson on Thursday, Feb 25, 2010 (Photo: Saul Young/News Sentinel) Buy Photo \n  \nWhat is the proper style for inserting a person\u2019s nickname into his or her written full name? \n \nMost stylebooks specify placing the nickname after the forename and enclosing it in quotation marks. Some stylebooks say parentheses may be used instead. \n \nExamples of the preferred form: General James \"Mad Dog\" Mattis, Coach Paul \"Bear\" Bryant, Prime Minister Margaret \"Iron Lady\" Thatcher. \n \nDictionaries say the word \"nickname\" comes from the Middle English term \"eke name.\" \"Eke\" means \"addition.\" A person with an additional name would have \"an eke name.\" \n \nThe term \"an eke name,\" when run together in speech, sounds like \"a neke name\"; thus \"nickname.\" \n \nDon K. Ferguson, retired U.S. District Court chief deputy clerk, is a former member of the Knoxville City Council. He may be reached at ferguson111@comcast.net . \n \nRead or Share this story: http://knoxne.ws/2jE3adL \n      0) { %> \n0) { %> \n\n0) { %> \n]]>","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Don Ferguson, Columnist"},"topics":[{"name":"Society news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Opinion latest","group":"Society"}],"title":"Grammar Gremlins: Use quotation marks when inserting nicknames","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Knox","zipCode":"37902","state":"Tennessee","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Knoxville","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Knox News Sentinel","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169669706","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"2983"},"name":"Knox News Sentinel","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Standard","Society"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.knoxnews.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?url=http%3A//knoxne.ws/2jE3adL&text=Grammar%20Gremlins%3A%20Use%20quotation%20marks%20when%20inserting%20nicknames&via=knoxnews","http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?url=http%3A//knoxne.ws/2jE3adL&mini=true","http://knoxne.ws/2jE3adL"],"sequenceId":"695201350098","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:06:03Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

The role required some gravitas, but also called upon his voice-acting skills. \n \n\"I had lines, so already that was a plus,\" Hamill said, taking a friendly dig at his wordless appearance in \"Star Wars: The Force Awakens.\" \n \n\u2014 \n \nOne of the more heartfelt standing ovations at the festival was given Thursday morning to filmmaker Jennifer Brea, after the last screening of her documentary \"Unrest,\" in which she chronicled her battle with myalgic encephalomyelitis (ME), commonly known as chronic fatigue syndrome. \n \nBrea called the movie's rollout at the festival \"probably the most incredible few days in my life,\" as a number of audience members stood and talks about how they have been affected by the disease. \n \nPart of the push behind \"Unrest\" is to lobby for increased funding for research on the often-misunderstood disease. There is no cure, and no sure treatment, though Brea said she is helped some by antiviral medication. \n \nShe also avoids mold, which some sufferers have found to exacerbate the disease. (In the movie, she and husband Omar Wasow take a trip to the Southwest, where the dry air helps keep mold down.) \n \nPart of her mold avoidance, she said, was relocating to Los Angeles. \"I may be the only person who moved to Los Angeles for the air,\" Brea joked. \n \n\u2014 \n \nThe one-on-one experiences of the VR Palace were a must-view at the festival, though it was nearly impossible to try them all in the allotted one-hour sessions. \n \nTwo of the works were goofy fun. Mindshow allowed the viewer to take on the persona of a space alien, interacting with a pre-recorded astronaut character (voiced by comedian Dana Gould) \u2014 and then turning the tables, playing the astronaut opposite the alien the viewer just recorded. Chocolate, a psychedelic music video with a track by the EDM artist Giraffage, invited the user to dance as a multi-tentacled creature who shoots chrome kittens out its hands. \n \nIn a much more serious vein was filmmaker Rose Troche's \"If Not Love,\" which follows one horrible scenario \u2014 a conflicted gay man leaves a sexual encounter, and in his self-loathing commits a mass shooting in a gay bar \u2014 and imagines what would be different if his sex partner had shown a little more compassion.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"SEAN P. {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:06:03Z","duplicateGroupId":"29396060581","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION GRADUATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"STUDENT LOANS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"SECONDARY SCHOOLS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"77"},{"name":"VOCATIONAL & TECHNICAL TRAINING","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"SOCIAL SECURITY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"74"},{"name":"WORKERS COMPENSATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"},{"name":"TAXES & TAXATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"66"},{"name":"ENDOWMENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"76"},{"name":"WAGES & SALARIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"FACTORY WORKERS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"77"},{"name":"PLUMBING & HVAC CONTRACTORS","domains":["IND"],"score":"69"},{"name":"TUITION FEES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"MACHINE TOOLS","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"STUDENTS & STUDENT LIFE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"MARKETING & ADVERTISING","domains":["IND"],"score":"50"},{"name":"STUDENT FINANCIAL AID","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"HIGH SCHOOLS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"PRIMARY & SECONDARY EDUCATION","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"PART TIME EMPLOYMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"HEALTH INSURANCE","domains":["IND"],"score":"50"},{"name":"EDUCATION SYSTEMS & INSTITUTIONS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"ADULTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"74"},{"name":"COLLEGE & UNIVERSITY PROFESSORS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"}],"wordCount":"593","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396060581&p=2kx&v=1&x=GZcOKObrFK0GtRVqUZguiw","id":"29396060581","content":"3:01 a.m. ET Jan. 29, 2017 \n   Buy Photo  \nGeorge Davis, a Tennessee Technology Center student in the industrial maintenance program, works on testing a circuit board Jan. 11, 2012. (Photo: News Sentinel file photo) Buy Photo \n  \nThe News Sentinel and other publications have had articles about recent college graduates unable to find employment. This is the tip of a scandal of unbelievable proportion and importance for our country. \n \nThe goal of education is allegedly to prepare kids for life and to earn a living. How is this goal met by giving young adults meaningless degrees in exchange for $50,000 or more in student loans or parents emptying savings that will need to be paid back in real dollars? This is a failure at so many levels. \n \nStart with parents. Kids in high school for the most part don\u2019t have part-time jobs. They have no experience with the workplace or what kind of vocation they might enjoy. They also have no idea that an employer needs to compensate them for the value that their work provides for the business. \n \nI once asked a group of students how much they expected to make right after college graduation. The answers ranged from $50,000 to $200,000 a year. The all expected to quickly earn even more. When I told them that they would be expected to provide the business with enough value to cover their wages, workers' compensation, Social Security, taxes, medical insurance, the lease on the building, advertising, marketing and, of course, sufficient profits to keep the shareholders happy and the paychecks cashing, they were dumbfounded. I then told them that they would need to provide the company with $125,000 of value to justify their $50,000 salary. That was the first time they heard that, I assure you. \n \nParents could start the process by sitting their kids down and explaining their work experiences or even getting them some part-time work instead of one more extracurricular activity. \n \nEducation also plays a role. We have taken vocational training out of high school. This has removed an important source of experience for students. They can\u2019t find a calling as an electrician, welder, machinist, mechanic, plumber, carpenter, HVAC installer/repairman or dozens of others if they aren\u2019t exposed to them. How old was the last repairman you hired? These types of courses need to be reinstated in high schools. \n \nAs for colleges, the two-year schools are doing their part. Universities are another matter. Most state schools pay their deans more money annually than many of their students will earn in their lifetimes. The professors are tenured and untouchable. The administrators are all involved in the support of the structure. The alumni pour money into the endowments, which are ridiculous for state schools supported in part by tax dollars. The students get annual tuition increases in spite of the schools sitting on million- or even billion-dollar endowments. We need to recognize the value of a college degree is in part calculated by the education industry, which is protecting its own interest. \n \nThe best example of career guidance I\u2019ve experienced was several years ago. My home needed sewer work. The young man in charge of the crew was not what I expected. He explained that after high school his father told him he wasn\u2019t going to college. He was going to learn the family plumbing business. His dad told him his business wasn\u2019t going to be obsolete or outsourced. Ten years later he owns the business. He told me he has one of his old buddies working for him -- one of the college graduates. \n \nDonald Southwell, Loudon \n \nRead or Share this story: http://knoxne.ws/2jDZUz5","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Donald Southwell, Guest columnist"},"topics":[{"name":"Society news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Education news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Opinion latest","group":"Society"}],"title":"Citizen's Voice: Students need part-time jobs, vocational classes","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Knox","zipCode":"37902","state":"Tennessee","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Knoxville","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Knox News Sentinel","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169669706","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"2983"},"name":"Knox News Sentinel","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Standard","Society"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.knoxnews.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["http://knoxne.ws/2jDZUz5"],"sequenceId":"695201354295","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:06:03Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:06:04Z","duplicateGroupId":"29396060585","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"COLLEGE STUDENTS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"OUTPUT & DEMAND","domains":["SUB"],"score":"74"},{"name":"COLLEGES & UNIVERSITIES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"TALKS & MEETINGS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"74"},{"name":"MENTAL HEALTH","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"MENTAL HEALTH PRACTICE","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"SUICIDE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"92"},{"name":"BOARDS OF DIRECTORS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"62"},{"name":"STUDENTS & STUDENT LIFE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"91"},{"name":"BUDGET PROPOSALS","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"BUDGETS","domains":["IND"],"score":"86"},{"name":"MENTAL ILLNESS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"DEPRESSION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"PSYCHOLOGY","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"},{"name":"EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION EMPLOYEES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"},{"name":"UNIVERSITY ADMINISTRATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"SCHOOL BUDGETS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"76"},{"name":"UNITED STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"}],"wordCount":"620","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396060585&p=2kx&v=1&x=FhBSaq7yvjNhzwGz8HvHdg","id":"29396060585","content":"3:01 a.m. ET Jan. 29, 2017 \n    \nClaudia Garcia (Photo: Submitted) \n  \nHearts broke all over the University of Tennessee\u2019s campus the morning of Sept. 6, 2016, as we heard of Andrew Vermillion\u2019s suicide. Vermillion, a 22-year-old fellow Vol, jumped off the 11th Street pedestrian bridge on campus. Unfortunately, suicides on college campuses are not that rare. According to www.collegedegreesearch.net , 1,100 college students die of suicide per year. Vermillion's tragic death and the deaths of so many college students around the country should be a call to action for universities to implement funding that keeps up with the growing enrollment rate and for counseling center services to be more publicized and accessible. College students are one of the most at-risk populations in the United States for anxiety and depression, which means it is imperative our Volunteers know their resources and have full access to them. \n \nWith the consistent rise in admissions rates on college campuses, the need to expand mental health services has significantly increased. In fact, the numbers of students who have seriously considered attempting suicide, injured themselves without suicidal intent, made a suicide attempt or considered hurting another person all went up between 2010-13, according to the American Psychological Association. Despite the growth in college enrollment each year, many universities have not adjusted their budgets appropriately for mental health and counseling services. \n \nAs the Center for Collegiate Mental Health determined, the demand for counseling services has been outpaced by enrollment rates five-fold. This means that in order to keep up with the enrollment rate of a university, administrators must increase the counseling center\u2019s budget by the same percentage. As for UT specifically, according to the Board of Trustees' annual meeting reports, the proposed budget increases the counseling center\u2019s budget by about 3.1 percent, but it is questionable if that will be enough to combat the increase in enrollment for next year. \n \nFunding is not the only problem. The stigma surrounding mental health is so prominent that college students are less likely to seek help, even though they may be the population that would benefit the most from it, according to the Journal of Medical Care Research and Review. \n \nKnowing that, it is imperative that the university community stand together to eliminate the stigma surrounding mental health issues. It is also vital that the university educate the student body about resources available to them. Resources like drop-in consultations, psychological assessments, crisis interventions, individual, couple and group therapy can be discussed in a Freshman 101 class or by the resident hall directors. These services are all free for students. \n \nIt is important to know that the mental health of students is not the responsibility of just the counseling center. Informing each other on coping strategies, being aware of our surroundings and of the emotions of others can encourage someone at risk to set up an initial consultation with the counseling center or be referred to another psychologist in town if they want to exceed the 12 allotted appointments that the counseling center gives. \n \nCollege can seem like another universe. Students must adjust like they have never had to before and peer relationships are crucial, which is why college students are at a high risk for suicide and serious mental health problems. If we stand together in true Volunteer fashion and promise to stomp out the mental health stigma, demand more publicity for mental health resources and counseling center services, and be vigilant with those around us, maybe we can all help prevent someone from committing suicide, and do justice to Vermillion. A forever Vol. \n \nUT students experiencing mental health issues or who know other students who are should contact the Student Counseling Center at 865-974-2196 or email counselingcenter@utk.edu. Vols help Vols. \n \nClaudia Garcia is a Knoxville resident.   \n \nRead or Share this story: http://knoxne.ws/2jDZXef","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Claudia Garcia, Guest columnist"},"topics":[{"name":"Medical news","group":"Science"},{"name":"Society news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Education news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Opinion latest","group":"Society"}],"title":"Claudia Garcia: UT students should know mental health help is available","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Knox","zipCode":"37902","state":"Tennessee","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Knoxville","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Knox News Sentinel","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169669706","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"2983"},"name":"Knox News Sentinel","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Standard","Society"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.knoxnews.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["http://www.collegedegreesearch.net/","http://knoxne.ws/2jDZXef"],"sequenceId":"695201354479","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:06:04Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

Still, I\u2019m thankful we\u2019re finally having a real winter to refresh our lakes and streams. That said, a few rainstorms needn\u2019t keep anyone housebound. Especially, not when you live in the heart of Central Coast wine country where our creative wineries offer some pretty great events every month of the year. \n   \nWith Valentine\u2019s Day a little over two weeks away, I\u2019ve found some very special ways of saying \"I love you\" to your sweetheart by taking part in a winery event, featuring great wines and delicious treats in Santa Ynez wine country. And more great news, some events will last through the month of February in Paso Robles. \n  \n Santa Ynez Wine Country  \n  \nZaca Mesa, founded in 1973, is notable because most wine industry insiders think of it as the university where many of our greatest local winemakers got their start. Not only that, most of them stayed here to create their own noble brands in Santa Barbara County. So the minds behind Zaca Mesa today have created Zaca University, naturally. They offer wine classes that are open to the public to help you better understand the magic that goes into the making of a bottle of fine wine. The upcoming class, \u201cSeduced by Syrah,\u201d takes place at their tasting room Feb. 11 from 11 a.m. to 2 p.m. It will provide a tasting experience to allow you to truly get to know their five unique syrahs during a tasting with the winemaking team and a certified sommelier. They describe the tasting as a \u201cdeeper look into the remarkable 2013 vintage.\u201d They will teach you to recognize the impact from each factor of making the wine, from farming the vines, the effects of the vintage (the year it was grown) to winemaking, has on each wine even though they are all grown in their estate vineyard. It\u2019s not only informative, it\u2019s fun. The price is $75 per person (wine club members get in for $60 per person), which includes lunch with Zaca Mesa\u2019s great team of people who are quite passionate about winemaking. Learn more and/or buy your tickets at www.zacamesa.com . \n  \n Solvang Wine Country  \n  \nThere are many new tasting rooms in Solvang. This quaint little town just keeps on growing better all of the time. But this special event, Solvang\u2019s Third Wednesday Wine and Beer Walk, which only happens once a year, is on Feb. 15 from 4 to 7 p.m. It\u2019s a great way to help you get to know some new tasting rooms. For only $20 per person, you can taste two samples at five wine and beer tasting rooms. The ticket price gets you a souvenir glass, and a map to make it convenient to find them all. You must be 21 or over. Purchase your tickets (cash only) on the day of the event at one of these three businesses: the Olive House at 1661 Mission Drive, Wandering Dog Wine Bar at 1539-C Mission Drive and Sort This Out Cellars at 1636 Copenhagen Drive, where you will also be able to pick up the Wine & Beer Walk logo glass and head out to make some new favorites. For more information, visit www.solvangthirdwednesday.com . \n   \n Get tips on free stuff and fun ideas delivered weekly to your inbox  \n  \n Paso Robles Wine Country  \n  \nWhether you live nearby or an hour away, Vina Robles in Paso Robles offers some compelling reasons to rank them among your favorite Central Coast tasting rooms. On three Saturdays during the month of February, they will provide free concerts at the tasting room. Not only is it complimentary, but reservations are not necessary. Their fine wines will be available, which you can purchase in flights (small pours of several different white and red wines), by-the-glass or by-the-bottle. They only ask that you do not bring in alcoholic products that they haven\u2019t made. They will also have tapas available for purchase to sate your hunger. The free events take place on Feb. 4, 18 and 25. \n   \nOn Feb. 11, they are offering a pre-Valentine\u2019s Day early evening tasting from 5 until 8 p.m., featuring a \u201cChocolate Festival.\u201d They have invited other wineries and several chocolate vendors in for a wine and chocolate tasting that will be exceptional. The cost is $40 per person ($35 per person for wine club members), with a portion of the proceeds going to the Big Brothers Big Sisters of SLO County charity. Singer-songwriter Melody Flemin will perform. She will also appear during the free concert on Feb. 4. Other artists will include Kenny Taylor on Feb. 18 and Whitherward, a nationally touring indie-folk duo, on the Feb. 25. Learn more about the free concerts and other concerts in their spectacular amphitheater (I saw Tony Bennett last year) at www.vinarobles.com . \n   \nThere are many more events going on, but I picked the ones that appealed most to me. {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:14:04Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395784618","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"OBJECT ORIENTED PROGRAMMING","domains":["IND"],"score":"73"}],"wordCount":"384","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396060751&p=2kx&v=1&x=p6JshNUsfdRd4zQMtzwf6A","id":"29396060751","content":"I have a entity-component-based game engine.   \n \nThere are many systems, e.g. System_A , System_B ,... all derived from SystemDefault . \n \nIf I want to use custom memory allocator, how can I used it in a real game?   \n \n  \n \nQuestion 1: Where is the field \"allocator\", how many of them? \n \nSolution 1A :  Store it in a top header.   There might be 3 types: stack, one frame, and heap. \n \nDisadvantage: \n \nMany systems will tend to use the share allocator, thus this solution may not give much advantage about cache coherence. \n \n  \n \nSolution 1B  :  Store it in each and every System.  (1-3 allocator per System) \n \nThe most appropriate way for a big game is adding a field \"memory pool\" for SystemDefault . \n \nDisadvantage: \n \nNot all memory-allocation demand is in System_xxx.  \n \nFor example :- \n Some AI or physic engines use its own architecture that is not component-entity.      Some custom datastructure may contain another small datastructure.  For these cases, how should allocator be passed?  \nSolution 1C  : Store it in each and every \"Allocator holder\" \n \nMake every class that want to allocate some memory derived from a certain class AllocatorHolder. \n \nDisadvantage:  crazy? \n \n  \n \nQuestion 2: How to enforce a code to use a certain allocator? \n \nSolution 2A : Use allocator of the system that contains the code. \n \nDisadvantage: There is a call like :- \n \n  \n \n//System_A  or System_B \n \nfA () or fB () { \n \n    loop {    \n \n        array = System_C :: doSomething () ; \n \n    } \n \n} \n \n  \n \nI don't think it is good - System_C::doSomething should use allocator of A, and B for each situation.  (right?) \n \nThat is C should aware what class is using it - not just blindly use its own C allocator. \n \n  \n \nSolution 2B : Passing allocator when calling every function. \n \nDisadvantage :  The call will be :- \n \n  \n \n//System_A  or System_B \n \nfA () or fB () { \n \n    loop {    \n \n        array = System_C :: doSomething (this) ;  //or this->stack_allocator or this->oneFrame_allocator, etc. \n \n    } \n \n         } \n \nNow, every function practically should have allocator as a parameter - ugly. \n \n  \n \nQuestion 3: How to initialize datastructure? \n \nIn my old code it is easy like this:- \n //inside SystemA\n    fA(){\n         MyArray ts;\n    }  \nShould I make it more harder like :- \n     fA(){   \n         MyArray ts;\n         ts.setAllocator(this->stackAllocator);    //applicable for 1A 1B 1C\n    }  \nor ... \n     fA(){\n         MyArray ts;    //applicable only for 1C\n    }  \n------------------------------------------------------ \n \n  \n \nThere are a lot of memory pool resources in the internet, but none mention how to use it in practice. \n \nHere is what I read:- \n Are we out of memory?                   (a popular article)  C++: Custom memory allocation    (very long, provide usable code)  \nHow do you manually manage memory-allocation in your game?","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Entertainment: video game news","group":"Entertainment"}],"title":"Apply memory pooling \"Alloc()\" in **real** game (with ECS)","source":{"category":"Consumer","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","countryCode":"US","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"GameDev.net","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"185631882","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"5"},"name":"GameDev.net","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Consumer","Recreation","Games"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.gamedev.net"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["http://www.swedishcoding.com/2008/08/31/are-we-out-of-memory/"],"sequenceId":"695201357410","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:14:04Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:06:06Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}
