{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:00:18Z","duplicateGroupId":"29393251372","companies":[{"symbol":"JALA","primary":true,"name":"Be Active Holdings Inc","contentCount":1,"exchange":"PINX","titleCount":0,"isin":"US0733012027"},{"symbol":"ELIS","primary":true,"name":"Elis SA","contentCount":1,"exchange":"PAR","titleCount":0,"isin":"FR0012435121"},{"symbol":"7EL","primary":true,"name":"Elis SA","contentCount":1,"exchange":"STU","titleCount":0,"isin":"FR0012435121"},{"symbol":"7EL","primary":true,"name":"Elis SA","contentCount":1,"exchange":"BER","titleCount":0,"isin":"FR0012435121"},{"symbol":"7EL","primary":true,"name":"Elis SA","contentCount":1,"exchange":"MUN","titleCount":0,"isin":"FR0012435121"},{"symbol":"7EL","primary":true,"name":"Elis SA","contentCount":1,"exchange":"FRA","titleCount":0,"isin":"FR0012435121"},{"symbol":"ELSSF","primary":true,"name":"Elis SA","contentCount":1,"exchange":"MEX","titleCount":0,"isin":"FR0012435121"},{"symbol":"GDI","primary":true,"name":"Good Idea SA","contentCount":1,"exchange":"WAR","titleCount":0,"isin":"PLGOODI00012"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"NOBEL PRIZES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"DISEASES & DISORDERS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"AGING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"AMINO ACIDS, PEPTIDES & PROTEINS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"76"},{"name":"MEDITATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"87"},{"name":"POPULATION & DEMOGRAPHICS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"AWARDS & PRIZES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"BIOTECHNOLOGY & GENETIC SCIENCE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"DNA","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"ANATOMY & PHYSIOLOGY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"DEATHS & DEATH RATES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"RESEARCH REPORTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"},{"name":"DIABETES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"},{"name":"EPIDEMIOLOGY","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"77"},{"name":"ELDER HEALTH","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"GENES & CHROMOSOMES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"CANCER","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"},{"name":"HUMANITIES & SOCIAL SCIENCE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"60"},{"name":"ENZYMES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"}],"wordCount":"1413","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396064271&p=2kx&v=1&x=0rf4RL5Ikc3wDg7tvEevTw","id":"29396064271","content":"The Nobel winner says keeping telomeres \u2013 the ends of our chromosomes \u2013 in prime condition can stave off diseases associated with ageing You won your Nobel prize for medicine for your discoveries concerning telomeres, found at the ends of chromosomes. What are telomeres and what happens to them as we age?\n\nIf you think of your chromosomes \u2013 which carry your genetic material \u2013 as shoelaces, telomeres are the little protective tips at the end. They are made of repeating short sequences of DNA sheathed in special proteins.\n\nDuring our lives they tend to wear down and when telomeres can\u2019t protect chromosomes properly, cells can\u2019t replenish and they malfunction. This sets up physiological changes in the body which increase risks of the major conditions and diseases of ageing: cardiovascular disease, diabetes, cancer, a weakened immune system and more. But the process is somewhat malleable. It is happening in all of us at some rate, but the rate can change. An enzyme called telomerase can add DNA to the ends of chromosomes to slow, prevent and partially reverse the shortening.\n\nCan you delay or reverse ageing by taking care of your telomeres?\n\nWe all have health spans \u2013 the number of years we remain healthy, active and disease-free \u2013 and the shortening of our telomeres contributes to ageing and our entry from health span into disease span. But we can [do things that] effect our telomerase and telomeres, that can [delay] entry from health span to disease span. So we are talking more about keeping people healthier for longer and staving off some diseases of ageing. This is not about extreme life span extension \u2013 though of course staying healthier longer does have a reflection in mortality rates.\n\nIn the book you argue that to lengthen our telomeres, or at least stop them shortening, we need to improve our lifestyle by managing chronic stress, exercising, eating better and getting enough sleep. A lot of these things are recommended already \u2013 so what is new?\n\nPeople hadn\u2019t understood why at the cellular level the sorts of things that are recommended to improve lifestyle can help stave off disease. One reason is because they are helping you maintain telomeres. The book integrates a lot of new studies \u2013 from genetics, epidemiology and social science \u2013 that have been accumulating. We also provide a new biological underpinning to the mind-body connection. Nobody had any idea that meditation and the like, which people can use to reduce stress and increase wellbeing, would be having their salutary and well-documented useful effects in part through telomeres. The book is also recognising how much control we can have. Small tweaks in how you approach stress, for example, can lead to long-term habits that make a difference.\n\nHow meditation might ward off the effects of ageing Read more One of the criticisms of the book is that it is a bit glib. That ageing is too complicated to simply boil down to these entities at the end of chromosomes\u2026\n\nThis is one of many processes of ageing, and we say that. We are focusing on one mechanism which has relatively recently been recognised in humans and that we can have some control over.\n\nWhat exercise can help preserve our telomeres?\n\nThe good news is you don\u2019t have to go to the gym three hours a day or run a marathon a week. People who do moderate aerobic exercise \u2013 about three times a week for 45 minutes \u2013 have telomeres pretty much as long as marathon runners. Mixing things up seems to be good too. One study showed the more different kinds of exercise people did, the longer their telomeres. Many studies looking at people under severe chronic stress find their telomere shortness relates to how severely that stress is experienced. But that relationship seems particularly strong in sedentary people. Even 10-15 minutes of light exercise daily appeared, in one study, to buffer the effect.\n\nBeyond a balanced diet with lots of wholefoods such as vegetables, fruits and grains, should we be taking any supplements to lengthen our telomeres?\n\nHaving adequate omega-3 fatty acids really seems to relate to better telomere maintenance and the easiest way to ensure that may be a supplement. It is also in foods such as oily fish and flaxseeds. There is some data about vitamin D but the studies are somewhat incomplete. It is pretty clear that if people have a balance much more towards a wholefoods diet versus a diet high in processed foods, red meat, sugary drinks and highly refined white bread \u2013 again, all the things we know already are bad for our health \u2013 you see quantifiable effects on telomeres.\n\nAre marriage and children telomere-friendly?\n\nThere is a general trend for longer telomeres among married people or those with partners. But we have also studied women who were formerly in relationships where they were domestically abused. Their telomeres were shorter, and the amount they were shorter related quantitatively to the number of years they were in the relationship. It probably relates to the stress of being in a threatening situation for a long period of time. One preliminary study has suggested having children may help telomere health but it has not yet been independently repeated, so it is early days.\n\nCan this woman cure ageing with gene therapy? Read more How quickly can telomere length change?\n\nYou can see the effects of interventions in as little as a few months. But it is really the long-term changes, over periods of a year to 10 years, that are going to be predictive of increased health span.\n\nCommercial tests are available for telomere length, with prices in the US ranging from about $100 to $500. Should we all get our telomere lengths tested?\n\nThe answer is no. I see no harm in it, but it doesn\u2019t mean a whole lot. You could be long one year and short another year. We know enough about telomere maintenance from a lot of studies to know the kinds of things that we can and should do. You want to do them regardless of what the test said.\n\nHave you had your telomeres tested?\n\nI had them tested because I was part of a research study. It turned out I had long telomeres. But that can change, so that test result doesn\u2019t stop me from taking seriously these lessons I have learned from all the research. I do try to build these things into my life. I exercise, but I don\u2019t spend hours at the gym; I have a good diet, but am not fanatical about food; and I try to think about the effect of stress. I practice micro-meditations which I think help.\n\nThere are pills that, it is claimed, have telomere lengthening effects, and at least one US company is developing telomerase gene therapy with the aim of reversing ageing. Are they a good idea to take?\n\nThese are things that purport to increase telomerase activity, but they are very untested and the studies that have been done have only been done by those who actually market these products. There is a caution too because telomerase has a good side (lengthening telomeres) but it can also have a bad side. Higher levels of it are associated with higher risks of brain tumours, melanoma and non-smokers\u2019 lung cancers. Things like exercise, stress reduction and good diet, on the other hand, have never been shown to increase cancer risk, and indeed some studies show they decrease those risks.\n\nAfter your experience on President Bush\u2019s Council on Bioethics \u2013 you were kicked off in 2004, many think for your support of human embryonic stem cell research \u2013 how do you feel about ?We need to be active. I am the president of a scientific research institute [the Salk Institute in San Diego]. We have to keep making clear statements about what sorts of things are important principles \u2013 including that science works because there is real respect for the truth. I expect there is going to be a mass shortening of telomeres around the country related to the chronic severe stress that will be a consequence if a number of Trump\u2019s policies come to pass. There is a likelihood of all these very burdensome diseases of ageing going up. We are in for big individual and societal costs.\n\n\u2022 The Telomere Effect: A Revolutionary Approach to Living Younger, Healthier, Longer by Elizabeth Blackburn and Elissa Epel is published by Orion Spring (£14.99). To order a copy for £12.74 go to bookshop.theguardian.com or call 0330 333 6846. Free UK p&p over £10, online orders only. {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:00:18Z","duplicateGroupId":"29393245183","companies":[{"symbol":"065560","primary":true,"name":"Cubes Inc","contentCount":1,"exchange":"KRX","titleCount":0,"isin":"KR7065560005"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"CHRISTMAS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"50"},{"name":"SCULPTURE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"PLASTIC BOTTLES","domains":["IND"],"score":"68"},{"name":"POLYPROPYLENE","domains":["IND"],"score":"61"},{"name":"MUSEUMS & GALLERIES","domains":["IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"EXHIBITIONS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"}],"wordCount":"1055","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396064272&p=2kx&v=1&x=vJeQO-lknyXZ0oyKw0xLDw","id":"29396064272","content":"Towner Art Gallery, Eastbourne\n\nAn exhibition on the theme of light is the latest to draw on the Arts Council\u2019s huge national collection. But how illuminating is it? A show about light: a light show \u2013 what might a curator put in? Just about all art concerned with making the world visible in some sense speaks of light, the very condition in which it was made. But an all-inclusive approach would be ridiculous, to be sure, so how about a show on light?\n\nYou could include Manet, who believed light was the main protagonist of any painting. You could put in Vermeer if you had the funds. You could look at the ever-changing effects of light in the art of Monet, or stuff the show with Constable, Turner and the American luminists, or blow your cash on a Caravaggio \u2013 or go the other way and show light art itself, from Dan Flavin to James Turrell. This is the besetting sin of theme shows: they put viewers into questioning mode, pondering what is and isn\u2019t relevant But the Towner Gallery hasn\u2019t gone this way at all. True, it has a small seascape by LS Lowry that is hardly lightsome in its turgid opacity. It also has a large Julian Opie sculpture that fuses one of Flavin\u2019s sublime neon works with a freezer cabinet in icily sinister pastiche. And Ceal Floyer has a bulb dangling from the ceiling that seems to emit an eerie blue glow (achieved by projectors) even though it\u2019s actually switched off.\n\nBy now it will be obvious that this is a conceptual event, multimedia, multifarious and intermittently tendentious. So there\u2019s the show itself to think of. The opening gallery is certainly all gorgeous radiance, generated by Cerith Wyn Evans\u2019s immense chandelier, flashing up a glumly obscure morse code message, to David Batchelor\u2019s marvellous cascade of coloured plastic bottles, each lit within like some abstract Christmas tree of the future. These lights send their reflections deep into Anish Kapoor\u2019s stainless steel void so that it looks more like a funhouse distorting mirror than an actual sculpture, playing subtly on voluminous depth. \u2018Gleaming wit\u2019: Gary Hume\u2019s Fragment of a Rainbow VI, 2011 at Towner, Eastbourne. Photograph: Pete Jones And there is the same lighting problem, so to speak, with Toby Ziegler\u2019s white on white painting, made in acrylic on polypropylene. Apparently we ought to be able to see Moorish columns, abstract designs and the extreme depth of field you get in computer games in its reflective surface. But what\u2019s mainly visible is the winking of Mark Titchner\u2019s wilfully hideous wool and lightbulb construction nearby. Gary Hume\u2019s Fragment of a Rainbow is a gleaming piece of wit: the colours of the spectrum all isolated in what appear to be massive, disembodied highlights of the shape one would normally find on a painted iris in a portrait, making the eye come alive. Red, green, yellow, blue and so on, these glossy panels carry their own reflections too: a triple play on light, and on the way we see light in art.\n\nAnd this is beautifully paired with an exquisite piece by Mark Garry that appears, at first, to be a beam of light passing at ceiling height between two galleries and then transforms into a light-splitting prism as you pass below. In fact it is nothing more than a sheaf of coloured threads stretched between two walls, affected by ambient air and the gallery spotlights. \u2018Voluminous depth\u2019: Untitled, 1995 by Anish Kapoor. Photograph: Pete Jones Here one sees how art makes poetry from science, specifically the behaviour of light. And there are other works here that take this even further, especially Garry Fabian Miller\u2019s beautiful experiments in the dark room, using light-sensitive paper but working entirely without a camera. Miller directs light, funnels it, and introduces liquids and filters to make what look like ethereal abstract paintings with some kind of nearly supernatural glow at their core.\n\nKatie Paterson\u2019s vast glitterball revolving between two projectors creates an ever-turning cosmos of stars gliding across the gallery walls. How far art has come from the static image\u2026 But each pinprick is the reflection of some miniscule image of a historic solar eclipse, 10,000 of them, reflecting the progression of an eclipse across the room. The vision is simple, rapturous, but the data is intensely complex.\n\nThere is some straight science here. Runa Islam\u2019s projection of a negative image flashes on for several seconds and then suddenly disappears, leaving a spectral positive of a woman\u2019s face on the mind\u2019s eye. This could be in the Science Museum, but at least it has something to do with light. It\u2019s pushing it to claim that Rachel Whiteread\u2019s resin cubes, cast from the spaces underneath chairs, are relevant in any way, still less Shirazeh Houshiary\u2019s modern reprise of Brancusi\u2019s Endless Column. As for John Riddy\u2019s show of a building in Barcelona, it has about as much to do with light as any pre-digital photograph. \u2018Spectral\u2019: Runa Islam\u2019s Stare Out (Blink), 1998. Photograph: © the artist This is the besetting sin of theme shows: they can put viewers into questioning mode, pondering what is and isn\u2019t relevant, how strong or weak the connections, what the entrance qualifications ought to be. This is no real way to look at art. Many shows rise high above this problem, but it is a test for viewer and curator alike, and particularly aggravated in this case.\n\nA year ago, the Arts Council announced that it had chosen four national partners to mount 24 \"must-see\" shows over three years, all derived from its massive collection. The partners were Yorkshire Sculpture Park, Birmingham Museums Trust, Liverpool\u2019s Walker Art Gallery and the Towner. The galleries get art and cash, the collection gets an England-wide airing and the public gets a glut of theme shows.\n\nAlthough it would be possible, in theory, to focus on solo artists such as Bridget Riley in which the collection is rich, or specific decades, or schools of art, nobody does it. So far it\u2019s been people, homes and the colour blue, with the decriminalisation of homosexuality to come. Not only are the curators limited to the collection, they are effectively in competition with each other. Hence, perhaps, the reliance on themes as a way of divvying up the art.\n\n\u2022 A Certain Kind of Light is at the Towner Art Gallery, Eastbourne until 7 {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T00:00:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395895858","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"SPORTS & RECREATION EVENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"SPORTS & RECREATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"69"},{"name":"CRICKET","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"NEW ZEALAND","domains":["GEO"],"score":"94"},{"name":"AUCKLAND, NEW ZEALAND; NEW ZEALAND","domains":["GEO"],"score":"78"},{"name":"AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"94"}],"wordCount":"593","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396064898&p=2kx&v=1&x=W9g5je_azKOaMfTeV5uyDg","id":"29396064898","content":"YOU would be hard pressed to find a shorter boundary in world cricket than the straight at Eden Park. \n \nBuilt primarily as a hunting ground for the All Blacks, the venue's straight boundaries are only about 55m away from the centre of the wicket. \n \nThose are the kind of dimensions that leave batsmen licking their lips. \n \nBut Australia's interim captain, Matthew Wade, has warned his batsmen to tread carefully at the Auckland ground on Monday when they take on New Zealand in the first of three one-day internationals. \n \n\"Looking at the small boundaries you assume really high scores but it is quite difficult,\" Wade said ahead of the first match of the Chappell-Hadlee Trophy. \n \n\"And it tends to swing here. That's something you've got to get through, the first 10-15 overs are crucial. With the line-up that we play, if we can have wickets in the shed at the back end then we will score a lot of runs at the end of the (innings).\" \n \nThe keeper found out the perils of taking on Eden Park's small boundaries when he played at the ground for the first time last February, caught at cow corner trying to heave Corey Anderson over the ropes. \n \nThe Australians were all out for 148 on that occasion, with the Black Caps' seamers running riot on the way to a 2-1 series win. It was a similar story a year earlier, with the Aussies skittled for 151 in a World Cup clash that the Kiwis only won by a wicket. \n \nAt the same time, Eden Park's unusual dimensions have resulted in big scores before. Although the tourists failed to pass 150 last time around, New Zealand posted a score of 8-307 in the same game. \n \nIndeed, before Australia's innings that day, seven of the last eight innings at the ground had gone past 280 runs. \n \n\"(The Eden Park pitch) just has a bit in it,\" New Zealand veteran Ross Taylor said. \"I don't think there is a par score, some wickets here are 300, some are 200. \n \n\"You just have to analyse it as quickly as possible, whether you're batting or bowling.\" \n \nThe Kiwis were trounced 3-0 in Australia when the sides met in December, but Wade is expecting a tougher time on New Zealand's turf. \n \n\"We played them in Australia (on) big grounds (with) long boundaries. It's a completely different ball game,\" he said. \n \n\"(On) the smaller grounds (in New Zealand) they'll still play aggressive; they're still going to be able to hit plenty of fours and sixes at grounds that they play at. \n \n\"They play well here (in NZ) and they play this venue very well. \n \n\"We like to think we're hard to beat in Australia and it's the same when we come here - we expect a hard challenge over the next three games but we've got a young squad and we're excited to go out and really have a crack at it.\" \n \nCaptaining the side for the first time, Wade maintains his job is simply to continue the fine work of the leadership duo of Steve Smith and vice-captain David Warner. \n \n\"I don't think for me personally it's about putting a stamp on the team,\" he said. \"It's about driving the values and the game plan that we have in one-day cricket moving forward. \n \n\"Steven and David have put their stamp on the team, it's just about me keeping on driving those key messages through to the players. \n \n\"We've performed really well in one-day cricket over a long period of time so it's not about trying to change too much - {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:49:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395964812","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"SURVEILLANCE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"},{"name":"ANIMALS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"CATS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; TEXAS, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"73"},{"name":"HOUSTON, TX, USA; UNITED STATES; TEXAS, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"73"}],"wordCount":"226","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396064590&p=2kx&v=1&x=D9s9W2hS7a5dTm9sdXFLWw","id":"29396064590","content":"HOUSTON, TX (KTRK/CNN) \u2013 A pet owner\u2019s two cats ended up stuck in her apartment walls, thanks to a distracted maintenance worker.\n\nNatalie Pradia\u2019s two tabby cats, named Ginger and Zelda, were seen on home surveillance footage playing around 10:30 a.m. Thursday. Then, their owner says her cats seemed to vanish.\n\n\"Rewind the cameras. Slow it down. Skip forward. Go backwards. The cats just seem like they poof, disappeared,\u201d she said.\n\nPradia assumed someone accidentally let the cats out, even though cameras didn\u2019t catch the animals fleeing out the front door. She and her family searched the neighborhood for hours with no luck.\n\nWhen they returned home, Pradia finally heard the cats\u2019 cries for help.\n\n\"I'm like, \u2018Where are you all, Zelda, Ginger?\u2019 Then I hear \u2018meow, meow,\u2019\u201d she said.\n\nPradia\u2019s daughters, Jerrica and Jazmynn, said the cats sounded like they were calling from under the floor. \n\n\"It sounded boxed in, so I figured they were stuck somewhere,\" Jerrica said.\n\nCrews cut through a downstairs neighbor\u2019s ceiling Friday morning to free Ginger and Zelda. The cats had been trapped inside the walls for more than 12 hours. \n\nWhile replacing tiles in the Pradias\u2019 bathroom, a maintenance worker created an opening, and the cats climbed through without him noticing. Staff at the apartment complex called this an unfortunate accident.\n\nGinger and Zelda seem to be doing fine after their adventure.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[],"title":"Woman finds cats stuck in apartment wall","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Charleston","zipCode":"29414","state":"South Carolina","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Charleston","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Live 5 WCSC","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169657452","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"148"},"name":"Live 5 WCSC","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.live5news.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695201464342","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:49:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:06:39Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://RAYCOMGROUP.images.worldnow.com/images/13012599_G.jpg"}],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T05:30:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29396064592","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"CITIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"57"},{"name":"US STATE GOVERNMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"CITY GOVERNMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; NEW YORK, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"KATHY HOCHUL","domains":["PEO"],"score":"57"}],"wordCount":"581","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396064592&p=2kx&v=1&x=Tyvwxn5cNAZ-pvrcWkl4rQ","id":"29396064592","content":"HUDSON - Assemblywoman Didi Barrett, D-106, was sworn in to her third term on Saturday at 3:30 p.m. at the Hudson Opera House. \n \nCounty and city officials, along with residents, were joined by New York state Lieutenant Governor Kathy Hochul to support Barrett. \n   Subscription Required  \nAn online service is needed to view this article in its entirety. Create one now.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Rosa Acheson Columbia-Greene Media"},"topics":[],"title":"Barrett sworn in to 3rd term","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Columbia","zipCode":"12534","state":"New York","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Hudson","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Register Star","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169685239","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"1"},"name":"Register Star","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Local","Geographic","News","Standard"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.registerstar.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695201464517","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T05:30:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:06:39Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/registerstar.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/b/d2/bd257038-e5b0-11e6-b5c0-af90e443fd1e/588d28567df0b.image.jpg?resize=300%2C200"}],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:00:19Z","duplicateGroupId":"29393254378","companies":[{"symbol":"2462","primary":true,"name":"LIKE Co Ltd","contentCount":1,"exchange":"TKS","titleCount":0,"isin":"JP3386120004"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"BIOGRAPHICAL LITERATURE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"LEGISLATIVE BODIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"TALKS & MEETINGS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"},{"name":"POLITICAL PARTIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"BIOGRAPHY PUBLISHING","domains":["IND"],"score":"72"},{"name":"POLITICS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"ADULTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"},{"name":"ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"},{"name":"PROFILES & BIOGRAPHIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"91"},{"name":"LONDON, ENGLAND","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"HILLARY RODHAM CLINTON","domains":["PEO"],"score":"67"},{"name":"HARRIET HARMAN","domains":["PEO"],"score":"89"}],"wordCount":"3841","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396064704&p=2kx&v=1&x=KdKt2Y0224gVXSbsePECZw","id":"29396064704","content":"The Labour MP has endured an a lot of abuse in almost 35 years in parliament. As she publishes her memoirs, the staunch loyalist explains why she\u2019ll keep fighting I always totally denounced people who wrote their memoirs, says Harriet Harman, who has just written her memoir. There is a copy of A Woman\u2019s Work in front of us. A hardback whopper of nearly 400 pages with all kinds of enticing entries in the index: Amalgamated Union of Engineering Workers, 18; Association of Metropolitan Authorities, 106; Mothers in Manufacturing Report, 219, 235. One thing I learn about Harriet Harman: she\u2019s not one to shy away from the boring detail.\n\nDuring her time on the frontbench, she says, people would sit in cabinet meetings and literally be writing their diaries in front of her. \"And I used to think, \u2018We\u2019ve got a country to run!\u2019 I was very moral high ground about it, all the time denouncing them as male vanity projects.\"\n\nSo, this is what? A female vanity project?\n\n\"Yes!\" she says. \"It\u2019s a self-consciously female vanity project. When all my colleagues\u2019 autobiographies came out, the first thing you do is to look at the photos and it would all be men. Maybe there\u2019d be their wife and someone who worked for them. And possibly Hillary Clinton and that\u2019s it. And it\u2019s like, where were the 100 women who swept into parliament? Where was the transformation reflected in our politics and the change in women\u2019s lives? You remember Sheila Rowbotham\u2019s Hidden from History? Her thing about unless it\u2019s written about, it\u2019s invisible and then it hasn\u2019t happened?\n\n\"Well, funnily enough, even though I was in the cabinet at the time, I don\u2019t seem to be in these memoirs either. You might find one reference, \u2018Harman, sacking of\u2019. And I thought, \u2018Well, stuff that\u2019. So I found it very easy to do my U-turn.\" Oh, it\u2019s raining men in the Labour party From someone else, this would be hypocritical self-aggrandisement. But this is Harriet Harman, AKA Harriet Harperson. Her conversation is littered with references to \"the cause\", \"the struggle\", \"the mission\" \u2013 her whole adult life, and her entire career at Westminster, has been in single-minded pursuit of equal rights. And it\u2019s fair to say that A Woman\u2019s Work is in some ways more about the changing political representation of women than it is about her. It\u2019s just that she defines and embodies that change.\n\nWe\u2019re in the kitchen of her house in her south London constituency, a warm, comfortable, family home with various piles of clutter and a prowling cat, the kind of fantasy dwelling that would make a millennial\u2019s heart bleed, and she\u2019s telling me how they bought it in 1987 when the area \"was all social workers and FE lecturers\". And now? \"Now it\u2019s bankers and corporate lawyers.\"\n\nWhen Harman first became an MP, at a byelection in 1982, London was a Tory stronghold, a family home was an achievable goal and she was one of only 11 women Labour MPs. And the only one who was pregnant. She was a completely new sight in British politics: a young, pregnant, feminist MP. The photos in the book show her campaigning with a babe in arms and then a toddler and they culminate in the still-record-breaking sight of the 101 Labour women elected during the 1997 landslide: Blair\u2019s Babes. Though she\u2019s still cross about that. The photo. Tutting when I bring it up.\n\nBecause there they all are, \"Folletted\" up in jackets all the colours of the rainbow, the prescribed style decreed by the Labour party\u2019s fashion arbiter, the then member for Stevenage, Barbara Follett, massed around a grinning Tony Blair. \"It was supposed to be the sisterhood!\" says Harman. \"It was supposed to be us, the women, doing it for ourselves. Not as the backing group for the great leader.\" Even more galling was the fact that it had been her idea. She\u2019d arranged it all, when suddenly at the last minute someone added Blair to the line-up. \"It was a complete failure to understand that this was a moment for women.\" On the other hand, she says, at least people remember it. Though she backtracks almost immediately. \"Though I think they would anyway.\" On the campaign trail in 1982, when she entered parliament. Photograph: Rex And a lot of it, of them, was down to her. Campaigning and networking and inspiring and ultimately helping to get the highly unpopular but effective all-women shortlists through, a struggle, documented at length, in the book. Alan Clarke\u2019s Diaries this is not, though she does recall how, as Robin Cook\u2019s deputy on the shadow frontbench, she had promised to take her son to the Bromley Odeon and, despite frantic calls to deliver a response to striking ambulance workers, she took him to the Bromley Odeon. Cook was furious. And since she couldn\u2019t think of an excuse, she simply told him: \"I was not available.\" Cook responded with \"conspiratorial glee\", she says. He assumed she was having an affair.\n\nBut then, having an affair was a valid excuse to go missing in action in Westminster. Having children was not. And Harman had three \"badly timed babies\". Pregnant in her first byelection, campaigning for her first general election with a four-month-old baby, pregnant for the second time when she joined the frontbench, and with another four-month-old baby at the time of her second general election in 1987.\n\nShe didn\u2019t have time to write a diary, she says, \"but because I was so on the defensive all the time, because I thought that people were thinking, \u2018Pregnant, baby, pregnant, baby, pregnant, baby, she\u2019s not going to be doing her job properly.\u2019 I had to prove myself all the time.\"\n\nAnd she fishes out children\u2019s scrapbooks filled with her old cuttings and a file of reports she gave to her local party. \"Look at this one,\" she says. \"You see. I report I\u2019ve had a baby but then I\u2019m immediately on to politics. \u2018They\u2019ve axed the physio in the maternity ward!\u2019 And I wrote that report on the 7th of December.\"\n\nWhen did you have the baby?\n\n\"November 20th. I just never thought I could be a normal MP. I always had to prove myself.\"\n\n\"She\u2019s always been fantastically dogged in pursuit of what she went into politics to achieve,\" one political editor tells me. \"It\u2019s just always been about the cause of women. And asserting herself as a woman in politics. I remember when she first starting stepping in at PMQs. On the one hand, she was leaden and heavy handed, but on the other, she was so relentless and unembarrassed that you came out just thinking, \u2018Good for her\u2019.\n\n\"She has been an extraordinary phenomenon in British politics. Just this totally driven political animal. Always nice. Always pleasant. Impeccably turned out. Incredibly professional. Fantastically loyal to the Labour party. But there are not many jokes or signs of life outside politics. It has always been about women and women\u2019s interests.\"\n\nAnd yet\u2026 it was a Tory who became Britain\u2019s second female prime minister. How did you feel about that? And she grimaces. It\u2019s a subject that is still raw. \"It\u2019s bad enough that the first one was. Imagine what that was like, if you\u2019re a feminist and in the women\u2019s movement, fighting against the Tories uphill and the first woman prime minister is a flipping Tory. It was torture.\"\n\nAnd now they\u2019ve gone and done it again. While the Labour party\u2026 \"Oh, it\u2019s raining men in the Labour party.\" It\u2019s pretty bad that the Tories have got a strong, competent woman in charge... \"It\u2019s terrible. It\u2019s bad. And this is the second time. But then there\u2019s a lot of things now, which are painful echoes of those years. It was bad enough first time around, but second time\u2026 \" It strikes me that in some way you\u2019re the Labour equivalent of Theresa May, I say. \"You mean Theresa May is the Tory equivalent of me?\" she says. And then shudders. \"I hope not!\" You\u2019re both senior, opinionated women, I point out, who don\u2019t care about being liked\u2026\n\n\"Please don\u2019t compare me to her. And I have no idea whether Theresa May wants to be liked. I don\u2019t want to be not-liked. It\u2019s just that nobody did for nearly 20 years. It was horrible and lonely and painful and I did it despite not being liked. I very nearly opted to leave. It\u2019s very difficult to be with people when they are meant to be your colleagues and they are being actively hostile.\n\n\"What kept me there was the women\u2019s movement. I was liked by them. I was one of them. We all liked each other. Theresa May and I are both female politicians but that\u2019s all.\"\n\nIt comes out in a heartfelt rush, this. Because, it\u2019s true, for a long time, Harman wasn\u2019t liked. Not by male-dominated Westminster and not by the male-dominated Westminster press. She was a humourless feminazi before the term was even invented. Harriet Harperson. Harridan Harman. In a column that is vile and misogynistic even by his own standards, Rod Liddle once wondered whether you \"would do\" Harriet Harman, if drunk enough, and decided on balance that you wouldn\u2019t. With husband Jack Dromey, now also an MP, in 1982. Photograph: PA It took 30 years of frontline politics before she gained even grudging acceptance. When she stepped down as deputy leader, the Daily Telegraph ran a leader with the headline: \"Hats off to Harriet Harman \u2013 like or loathe her \u2013 she\u2019s tough as old boots\" and noted that she endured more abuse than any other modern Labour politician bar Tony Blair.\n\nHarman\u2019s father was a doctor and her mother had trained as a lawyer \u2013 one of the first to graduate in the subject from Oxford \u2013 though she never practised. Harman says she and her three highly competitive sisters were brought up with \"mixed messages\" \u2013 the expectation that they would be educated, independent, accomplished in their own right and marry well. The aim, she says, was \"to be intelligent but not too clever\".\n\nIt was partly due to her background, suggests Yvonne Roberts, the Observer\u2019s former leader writer and a fellow member of the women\u2019s movement of that era, that she was enabled to rise above the resistance and hostility she encountered. Her parents sent her to St Paul\u2019s, the London public school that Harman describes as \"stiflingly elitist\". Roberts describes her as \"supportive and warm-hearted and quite posh. I think her background helped. I don\u2019t think anyone else but her could have carved their way through in the way she did. She was surprised if anyone challenged her. She had that same sense of entitlement that upper-class men have: \u2018Why shouldn\u2019t I be doing this?\u2019\n\n\"I think it\u2019s quite hard to knock her confidence. Though there have been times. But in her generation, our generation, it\u2019s kind of what you expected. You had to be ready for it. No one thought it was going to be an easy ride.\" At the University of York, her tutor suggested she\u2019d get a 2.1 if she slept with him, a 2.2 if she didn\u2019t. A few pages later, she writes about how the partner of the law firm where she was an articled clerk groped her. And she names them both. Are they dead? I ask her. Is that a bit problematic accusing people no longer around to defend themselves? She shrugs. \"They shouldn\u2019t have done what they did.\"\n\nIt was a burgeoning sense of injustice that led her to volunteer after work at the Fulham Legal Advice Centre, which, she says, is where she found her calling and became involved in the spectrum of 1970s radical causes: leftwing politics, the women\u2019s movement and consciousness-raising groups. Though there was too much talk about sex and not enough about equal pay for her taste. We were in the wilderness for so long, and the price was paid by people who were unemployed and had no decent services \"I just wasn\u2019t into group discussions about sex. There were also a lot of men on the left who felt it was the duty of women on the left to have lots of sex with them. Anyway, I didn\u2019t want to be discussing my own consciousness. I wanted to be discussing women\u2019s rights.\"\n\nBy this time, she\u2019d met Jack Dromey, then a trade unionist, now an MP, and her future husband, though they would never have done anything as bourgeois as go on a date. Did your eyes meet across a burning brazier?\n\n\"Something like that. Or a courtroom. I\u2019m not sure anyone went on dates in our world because we literally were full on with the cause. It was our lives. We didn\u2019t do chilling around and relaxing and being cheerful with Margaret Thatcher as prime minister. No. There was a job to be done.\"\n\nI get the distinct impression that Dromey is not the type to run around the house with a vacuum, though she won\u2019t be drawn on details. \"You\u2019ve got to remember that this is still a work in progress about men having an equal share in the home,\" she says.\n\nShe won\u2019t say either if she brought up her two sons (she has a daughter too) to be good feminists around the house, though one, Joe, has followed his parents into politics \u2013 he\u2019s a Labour councillor in south London. But one of the most affecting bits is where she talks briefly about her marriage. How, during her campaign to become deputy leader, Dromey would drive through the night so she could make a meeting. And how at the last minute, the party decided to release the full membership lists and her campaign manager, Joan Ruddock, said that to have a chance, they needed to leaflet them all and that would cost £40,000. Which they didn\u2019t have. She came around to the house to tell her and Dromey immediately said that they would find it: they would remortgage the house.\n\n\"I was absolutely astonished by that. Really astonished. Because it\u2019s a big, big sum of money. And Jack comes from a very poor background with no money at all. But he\u2019s always been so committed. So if I\u2019d come back from work exhausted and say I just couldn\u2019t face going to some meeting, some husbands would say, \u2018Just put your feet up and tell them you can\u2019t come.\u2019 Whereas Jack would say, \u2018Just put your head round the door for five minutes.\u2019 We\u2019ve got a shared belief system but in a way that\u2019s why we got together. We didn\u2019t come from the same backgrounds at all. We had shared goals.\"\n\nA week after I interview her, after the supreme court ruling, I ring to find out how she\u2019s going to vote on Brexit and she bangs on about how \"the moment of decision has passed\" and her constituents were telling her on Saturday that \"they thought it had already happened\". Eventually she says: \"I will vote with the whip.\" So, how did Peckham and Camberwell vote? \"Oh, very strongly Remain.\" So, you\u2019re not actually representing them at all, I say. You went on and on about how you shouldn\u2019t be in politics if it\u2019s not all about representing your constituents and yet here you are not representing them. From there on in, we get into what I can only call a slightly bad-tempered row. This is the other Harman, the dogged party loyalist, who has never, ever not toed the party line. She refuses to pass comment on Corbyn though it\u2019s obvious that she hates everything he stands for. And when I say, how deeply disappointing it is that Labour is just not providing any sort of opposition, she agrees, before listing the reasons why she\u2019s backing Corbyn and not providing any sort of opposition.\n\nThough if anyone knows about the political wilderness, it\u2019s Harman. Her first 15 years in parliament were spent in opposition. \"We lost four general elections: 79, 83, 87, 92. Four! The press used to say, Labour\u2019s absolutely useless. There\u2019s no opposition. We weren\u2019t even effective in opposition, let alone looking like a credible government.\"\n\nSo exactly what it feels like now? \"Exactly. Different circumstances. But that sense of being off the pitch, that we\u2019re irrelevant. That we can\u2019t do our basic job of representing our constituents. That absolutely frustrating thing. I just felt like, \u2018Come on!\u2019\" With Gordon Brown at the Labour party conference in 2008. Photograph: Martin Argles for the Guardian In her memoir, she rails against her neighbouring MP Stuart Holland, who threw in the towel to take some plum job. \"It was shocking to me that an MP would give up his seat this way and thereby run the risk of Labour losing the byelection,\" she writes.\n\n\"I wrote that before I knew about Jamie and Tristram,\" she points out. Jamie Reed and Tristram Hunt have both stood down as Labour MPs, triggering byelections. \"Tony Blair used to say it too. \u2018I don\u2019t know why I\u2019m doing this. I should go back to being a barrister.\u2019 And I used to say, \u2018If we all did that, where would we be.\u2019\"\n\nBut then, I say, isn\u2019t that what happens when you parachute careerist high-flyers into constituencies they have no connection to? Isn\u2019t this New Labour\u2019s chickens coming home to roost?\n\n\"All I can say is how I did it and what I said to Tony Blair. If you\u2019ve made a promise to your voters that you will stand up for them, you need to stand up for them. Nobody makes you stand as a Labour MP. You fight for that position. If I\u2019d just seen this as a career, I never would have done it. It was because it was a cause. And the cause is when you\u2019re opposition as well as government.\"\n\nThere was a moment in her career, though, when she could have stood up and been counted, and if she\u2019d done that it is conceivable that\u2026 well, it depends how counterfactual you want to be, but Gordon Brown would have been deposed, a new, less paranoid leader elected, the Tories would not have got in, the referendum would not have been called and Brexit would have been averted\u2026 It was in 2009, when James Purnell resigned, telling Brown he should quit and was followed by half the shadow cabinet, culminating in Caroline Flint accusing Brown of using women as \"window dressing\" when she stood down as Europe minister.\n\nDespite being deputy leader, Brown had refused to make Harman deputy prime minister, an act that she found humiliating and depressing, not just for herself, and I believe her on this, but for all Labour women. And she\u2019s right: it was important. And then in the middle of the crisis, she discovered that he planned to make Peter Mandelson deputy instead.\n\nIn the memoir, she recounts her fury. \"Over my dead body!\" she tells him. And then points out that she\u2019s about to go out and defend him against accusations that he treats women as window dressing. He backs down and agrees not to make Mandelson deputy prime minister. \"I was pleased but suspicious,\" she writes. \"And as I left my parting shot was, \u2018OK, but you\u2019d better not be going to double-cross me and do it by the back door.\u2019\" Harman with her three children in 1988. Photograph: Rex Later that afternoon, Brown made Mandelson \"first secretary of state\" or as Number 10 briefed the media, \"deputy prime minister in all but name\". It still smarts. She\u2019s still furious. But you wouldn\u2019t have known any of this at the time. She\u2019s shown dogged loyalty in the face of betrayal, knifings in the back, rank incompetence on the part of her colleagues, no-hopers as leaders. You\u2019ll never get her to bitch and whine. \"She\u2019s fantastically loyal to the Labour party,\" one political editor tells me. \"When she was fired by Blair very early on, she could have become a carping anti-Blairite but she just got on with it and eventually resurfaced as solicitor general and made a very good job of it.\"\n\nShe\u2019s no longer sees Brown or Blair, but she still refuses to be a carping anti-Blairite; when I point out that Iraq only occupies a page and a half of the entire book, she refuses to apologise for it. \"We\u2019d lost four elections. If you\u2019d been in opposition since 1982 with your constituents dying on hospital waiting lists, and I\u2019m not saying that people didn\u2019t die in Iraq. Obviously, they did in huge numbers, but I\u2019m not going to say bad things about him. We were in the wilderness for so long and the price that was paid was by people who were unemployed and had no decent public services; Tony was part of moving things forward.\"\n\nThis wasn\u2019t her first view of him. She\u2019d been friends with Cherie through their work in the law and thought she was \"a dynamo\". Tony, on the other hand\u2026 \"I thought that\u2019s it, the Labour party has gone to the dogs. I was amazed he got selected for Sedgefield. Couldn\u2019t imagine what had happened to everyone else\u2019s nominations.\"\n\nBut he was a winner. And, in the Harriet Harman playbook, that\u2019s what matters. Winning. Making laws. Changing things. \"It\u2019s not very fashionable, but I\u2019ve not got a bad word to say about Tony Blair in the book and I\u2019m not going to say a bad word afterwards because actually, he led us to three victories. Three victories where we could do things and I think the things we did were incredibly important. We did civil partnerships, we abolished Clause 28. The Human Rights Act\u2026 \"\n\nYvonne Roberts says what Harman and that cohort of women Labour MPs achieved for women during those years shouldn\u2019t be underestimated. \"On childcare and working rights and domestic violence. There was a lot of stuff going behind the scenes. I suspect she did more than she even takes credit for.\"\n\nThere is something bracing about talking to Harriet Harperson. I leave her kitchen feeling slightly more cheerful than when I arrived. It\u2019s so dark right now. \"But I remember feeling very dark and despondent when we had Reagan and Thatcher,\" she says. \"People talked about emigrating. But nobody went anywhere. We fought our way through. We kept the faith. We kept the course. We got into government. And that\u2019s what we\u2019ll do again.\" She\u2019s 66. It would be cheering to think there will finally be a female Labour prime minister in her lifetime. Or any Labour prime minister.\n\n\u2022 A Woman\u2019s Work by Harriet Harman is published by Allen Lane (£20). To order a copy for £15 go to bookshop.theguardian.com or call 0330 333 6846. Free UK p&p over £10, online orders only. Phone orders min p&p of £1.99\n\nHarriet Harman speaks to Decca Aitkenhead for Guardian Live on 21 Feb, Islington Assembly Hall, London N1. Their ninth meeting in a grand slam final is all the sweeter for being so unexpected. \n \nLast October, Federer travelled to Mallorca for the opening of his friend\u2019s new tennis academy. The Swiss was on \u201cone leg\u201d after knee surgery and the Spaniard still hampered by the wrist injury that wrecked his 2016 season. \n \n\u201cAt that moment, for sure we never thought that we had the chance to be in a final again, and especially in the first of the year,\u201d recalled Nadal. \n \n\u201cBoth of us I think worked very hard to be where we are. It\u2019s great that we are again in a moment like this.\u201d \n \nAs Nadal and Federer arrived at Melbourne Park as ninth and 17th seeds, therefore, the first drafts of the obituaries of two great sporting careers were being prepared. \n \nThey were hurriedly dropped back into the files, however, as it became apparent the duo were playing vintage tennis: Federer all fluidity and peerless shot-making, Nadal at his brutal best from the baseline. \n \nThe early departures of reigning champion Novak Djokovic and top seed Andy Murray, the players who had joined Federer and Nadal to make up the \u201cBig Four\u201d, then opened up the path to a grand final reunion. \n \nAlthough it has often felt more like 2007 than 2017 at Melbourne Park this week, even great champions are not immune to the ravages of time. \n Recovery time  \nAt 35, Swiss Federer is the oldest men\u2019s grand slam finalist since Ken Rosewall lost the US Open final in 1974 at the age of 39. \n \nNadal might be five years younger but has been on tour since his late teens and the effort required for his attritional playing style puts tremendous strain on his body. \n \nAnd while Federer has been able to rest up after his three-hour semi-final victory over Stan Wawrinka on Thursday, Nadal must recuperate as best he can after his epic five-hour victory over Grigor Dimitrov on Friday. \n \n\u201cThat\u2019s what I\u2019m going to try,\u201d the 14-times grand slam champion said. \u201cI did it in 2009. I am seven, eight years older.\u201d \n \nThat five-set 2009 victory over Federer earned Nadal his sole Australian Open crown and another would make him the only man in the open era apart from Roy Emerson to have won all four grand slams twice. \n \nFederer has four Australian Open titles but just a single French Open crown, his path to Roland Garros glory more often than not blocked by Nadal. \n \nNadal has a 6-2 edge over Federer in grand slam finals but few are making a call with any confidence over who will win today\u2019s contest. \n \n\u201cI just know that two of the greatest players of tennis are going to square off on Sunday, and it\u2019s going to be a freakin\u2019 amazing match,\u201d Dimitrov said on Friday.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Nick Mulvenney"},"topics":[{"name":"Oceania latest","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Sports: tennis news","group":"Sports"}],"title":"Deja vu slam to climax with Roger-Rafa show","source":{"category":"Trade","location":{"region":"Europe","subregion":"Southern Europe","countryCode":"MT","country":"Malta"},"editorialRank":"3","name":"Times of Malta","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169660702","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"87"},"name":"Times of Malta","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Tennis","Sports","Consumer"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.timesofmalta.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695201476313","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T05:11:04Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:06:44Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:06:44Z","duplicateGroupId":"29396065360","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"PRODUCT ENHANCEMENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"}],"wordCount":"287","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396065360&p=2kx&v=1&x=0P3UL4o6stsIbQ3-Vf-eQw","id":"29396065360","content":"Microsoft formally announced Visual Studio 2017 a few months ago , and offered a release candidate as well. The integrated development environment (IDE) had been in preview for quite some time under the name Visual Studio \"15\" , and offers various improvements and enhancements over previous versions, included an increased focus on mobile cross-platform development. \n \nThe company has now released another update for the IDE , integrating new features and fixing a number of issues. \n  \nMicrosoft has released a summary of the change log relevant to the latest update to Visual Studio 2017 Release Candidate. It includes: \n The .NET Core and ASP.NET Core workload is no longer in preview. We have fixed several bugs and improved usability of .NET Core and ASP.NET Core Tooling.  Team Explorer connect experience is now improved to make it easier to find the projects and repos to which you want to connect.  The Advanced Save option is back due to popular demand.  Multiple installation-related issues are now fixed in this update, including hangs. We\u2019ve also added a retry button when installation fails, disambiguated Visual Studio installs in the Start menu, and added support for creating a layout for offline install.  \nMoreover, the company has also removed Data Science and Python Development workloads. Microsoft explains that as the IDE approaches public release, many components including the ones mentioned above, won't be able to meet some necessary requirements - such as translation to non-English languages. As a result, they'll be available as separate downloads later. \n \nMicrosoft has encouraged users of the release candidate to report bugs , track feedback on developer forums , and voice suggestions on UserVoice . Before going into any other part of what happened, we need to say - thank you. Thank you for being the crazy misfit who thinks he can change the world. It\u2019s men like you who make history. We aren\u2019t sure, whether to start with lauding your courage or  apologising  on behalf of a handful of goons who took it upon themselves to safeguard the Rajput culture. Zaira, for days after her social media post, stayed indoors. A friend in Srinagar had informed us how her parents refused to open the doors to anyone and kept the phones unplugged or switched off. They were petrified for her safety. \n \n  \n \nThe cited instances bring us to the point that Bollywood is a soft prey for anti-social groups. The goons claimed that they were  vandalising  the set to protest inappropriate depiction of their history. Pray, how did they know what the film\u2019s script has? For a film that\u2019s mounted on a magnanimous budget, the cost of equipment damaged by your silly act of so-called righteousness will be borne by the poor producers, who wouldn\u2019t want any further harm to their passion project. {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:06:50Z","duplicateGroupId":"29396065968","companies":[{"symbol":"TAX","primary":true,"name":"Tax Systems PLC","contentCount":1,"exchange":"LON","titleCount":0,"isin":"GB00BDHLGB97"},{"symbol":"RVUB","primary":true,"name":"Tax Systems PLC","contentCount":1,"exchange":"STU","titleCount":0,"isin":"GB00BDHLGB97"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"TAX RELIEF","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"LEGISLATIVE BODIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"GRANDCHILDREN","domains":["SUB"],"score":"61"},{"name":"TAX DEDUCTIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"79"},{"name":"TAX LAW","domains":["SUB"],"score":"91"},{"name":"TAX REFORM","domains":["SUB"],"score":"92"},{"name":"US REPUBLICAN PARTY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"ESTATE PLANNING","domains":["IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"US FEDERAL GOVERNMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"POLITICAL PARTIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"US PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES 2016","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"TAXES & TAXATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"93"},{"name":"LEGISLATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"INCOME TAX","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"},{"name":"AFFLUENT MARKET","domains":["IND"],"score":"73"},{"name":"PERSONAL FINANCE","domains":["IND"],"score":"79"},{"name":"GENERATION SKIPPING TRANSFER TAX","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"PUBLIC FINANCE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"MARRIAGE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"60"},{"name":"POLITICS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"US DEMOCRATIC PARTY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"ESTATE TAX","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"93"},{"name":"WILLS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"WEALTHY PEOPLE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"74"},{"name":"FILIBUSTER","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"APPROPRIATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"GIFT TAX","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"EUROPE","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"DONALD TRUMP","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"1099","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396065968&p=2kx&v=1&x=-tX08Bf6T9ZOOzPjO-d5Jg","id":"29396065968","content":"Comprehensive federal tax reform likely will be a top priority for the Trump administration and Republicans in Congress in the first half of 2017. Although there are differences between their proposals, President Donald Trump and the House GOP have suggested significant changes to the estate tax as well as to the availability of asset step-up in basis after death and itemized deductions during life. High-net-worth individuals and their estate planners should examine all three issues, in addition to state estate tax consequences, when revising their lifetime and testamentary giving plans in the wake of changes at the federal level. \n Tax Reform Plans  \nThe following table compares President Trump\u2019s statements on tax reform during his campaign with the House Republican proposal, known as the \u201cBlueprint.\u201d (See \" Business Tax Reform All but Certain in US, Europe .\") \n \nPresident Trump and the Blueprint offer additional proposals, such as closing the carried interest tax \"loophole\" (President Trump only) and income tax rate decreases for corporations and pass-through business entities (both plans). However, the issues of estate tax repeal, changes to asset basis step-up and limitations on deductions will have the most significant effects on estate planning in terms of both testamentary plans and lifetime giving. \n Estate Tax Repeal  \nEstate tax repeal has been on the Republican wish list for many years, but previous efforts at permanent repeal failed \u2014 even during one period of unified Republican government \u2014 because of Democratic political opposition and legislative rules relating to the reconciliation process between House and Senate spending bills. However, political will for estate tax repeal is strong this year, both because it is a stated priority for congressional Republicans and President Trump and because Senate Democrats may cede opposition to estate tax repeal as a filibuster bargaining chip in overall tax reform. The generation-skipping transfer tax, which prevents individuals from avoiding the estate tax through transfers to grandchildren and more remote descendants, would become largely irrelevant with no estate tax in place and would likely be part of any estate tax repeal bill. \n \nAlthough the 40 percent rate for transfers at death totaling over $5.49 million for an individual and $10.98 million for a married couple in 2017 appears ripe for the legislative chopping block, less certain is the status of the gift tax. Neither plan mentions this tax, which imposes the same rate on transfers exceeding the same amounts during a donor\u2019s lifetime. Although transfer taxes represent only a nominal amount of revenue for the government relative to all tax receipts, the gift tax serves as a backstop to the income tax by preventing high-marginal-rate taxpayers from gifting certain assets to low-marginal-rate taxpayers \u2014 often, younger family members \u2014 who would sell the assets and gift the proceeds back to the donor. If the gift tax remains in effect, transfer techniques such as grantor-retained annuity trusts would continue to be effective estate planning tools even after a repeal of the estate tax. \n Asset Basis Step-Up  \nA major difference between the two plans is whether assets that appreciate will receive a step-up in basis, or a readjustment in value, at an owner\u2019s death. Current law and the House GOP plan provide that all assets owned by a decedent at his or her death receive a step-up in basis to their fair market value at the time of death. Unless an asset appreciates significantly after the decedent\u2019s death, its recipient will have limited \u2014 if any \u2014 taxable gain on a later sale or exchange. \n \nHowever, President Trump\u2019s plan appears to limit the step-up in basis to the first $10 million of built-in gain in assets owned by a decedent at death. If a decedent owned $100 million of assets at death with an aggregate basis of $50 million (in the simplest case, having paid $50 million for those assets, which then appreciated to $100 million), the basis of those assets in the hands of the recipient(s) would be limited to $60 million as opposed to their $100 million fair market value. It is unclear from President Trump\u2019s plan how the $10 million increase in basis would be allocated among multiple built-in gain assets. It also is unclear whether his plan would deem death a capital gains realization event, such that, in the previous example, the decedent\u2019s estate would pay tax (presumably, at capital gains rates) on $40 million of appreciation, and the recipients would take the decedent\u2019s assets with a $100 million fair-market-value basis. In any event, the full, tax-free step-up in basis at death that estate planners and clients have enjoyed would no longer be in effect. \n Limitations on Deductions  \nFinally, President Trump\u2019s plan changes the availability of itemized deductions for all taxpayers, potentially limiting the income tax efficiency of charitable contributions during life for charitably inclined high-net-worth individuals. Although the House GOP plan eliminates most itemized deductions, such as deductions for medical expenses and for state and local taxes, it retains the current charitable deduction, which is unlimited in terms of dollar value but subject to a percentage limitation based on adjusted gross income. \n \nBy contrast, President Trump\u2019s plan retains all current itemized deductions but caps them at $100,000 for a single individual and $200,000 for a married couple. An individual whose annual home mortgage interest, medical expenses, and state and local taxes exceed $100,000 would thus receive no additional deduction for amounts contributed to charities, perhaps causing him or her to defer charitable giving to later years or until death. \n State Estate Taxes  \nEven if President Trump and the House GOP implement comprehensive tax reform that eliminates the federal estate tax, state estate taxes would not automatically follow suit. New York, for example, imposes an estate tax with a top rate of 16 percent for transfers at death exceeding $4.187 million (increasing to $5.25 million in April 2017). Eighteen other states have state estate taxes, with top rates ranging from 12 percent to 20 percent. New York residents and residents of other states that continue to have separate estate taxes must remember to consider the state tax efficiency of their estate plans, even if state estate tax rates remain lower than the current top federal rate of 40 percent. \n Looking Ahead  \nAt first glance, changes to the transfer tax system at the federal level would seem to simplify estate planning for many individuals. However, because of offsetting changes to the federal income tax consequences of gratuitous transfers and unchanged state transfer tax systems, individuals and their estate planners should take a cautious approach when revising estate planning documents in the coming year. \n \nThis memorandum is provided by Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP and its affiliates for educational and informational purposes only and is not intended and should not be construed as legal advice. DEPARTMENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"FOREIGN INVESTMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"91"},{"name":"UNITED STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"95"},{"name":"DONALD TRUMP","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"1027","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396065949&p=2kx&v=1&x=ak0bgFCfjnvdV2eKiUhGNQ","id":"29396065949","content":"President Donald Trump has made foreign trade and foreign competition main areas of focus early in his presidency. The new administration\u2019s appointments reinforce expectations of a multipronged approach to foreign investment and specifically to reviews by the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS). While most foreign acquisitions and investors will continue to be welcomed, those presenting potential national security issues \u2014 which the Trump administration may come to view as including risks to American jobs and pre-eminence in certain industrial sectors \u2014 can expect more searching CFIUS reviews. \n \nTrump Administration. Additional subcabinet appointments to executive positions within key agencies will further clarify the new administration\u2019s approach. Early indications suggest it will be open to investments from friendly nations but more skeptical of those from nations it deems to be economic or strategic adversaries or engaging in trade-distorting practices. Notably, the long-standing split within CFIUS between economic and national security agencies may become more stark in the Trump administration. Appointments to the Trump cabinet in key economic positions, including Treasury, State, Commerce and the National Economic Council, indicate an administration preference for practical dealmaking, given top-level appointees\u2019 experiences in the private sector. At the same time, some key economic appointees have indicated that the CFIUS process may not be adequately addressing trade issues, such as reciprocal market access. For example, during confirmation hearings, Commerce secretary nominee Wilbur Ross Jr. was asked about CFIUS reviews of Chinese acquisitions in the entertainment industry. Ross indicated that he was \u201cstruck to learn\u201d that the industry is \u201cnot very reciprocal [in] that [Chinese investors] want to control entertainment and other media here, and yet are denying our companies anything getting remotely close to that.\u201d Moreover, the administration also has signaled through its appointments at Defense and Justice that it may be highly skeptical of investments from geopolitical rivals and can be expected to encourage a more rigorous and thorough review of investments from those nations. \n \nJob Retention. Foreign investors can expect all of these agency priorities to yield at times to the unifying principle of President Trump\u2019s foreign investment platform: maintaining domestic employment. Treasury secretary nominee Steven Mnuchin nodded to this possibility when referring during his confirmation hearing to a potential committee role in \u201cprotecting American workers.\u201d In addition, during the transition, the incoming president broadcast his meetings with CEOs and foreign investors, such as Masayoshi Son of Japan, who have committed to expanding employment and keeping facilities and technology in the United States. As shown in those transition discussions and in the recent Carrier and Ford onshoring decisions, investors who commit to maintaining jobs in the United States can expect more favorable treatment in the Trump administration. \n \nReciprocal Market Access. The president\u2019s continuing emphasis on reciprocal market access, as shown in senior White House appointments, also demonstrates that countries with strong bilateral trade relationships with the United States should continue to enjoy a more favorable position in transactions before CFIUS. Still, while individual cabinet members have significant control over the strategies of their cabinet departments, senior and mid-level political appointees \u2014 who may not be named for several months \u2014 will ultimately be responsible for overseeing the day-to-day activities of government officials and making the majority of CFIUS decisions. Close attention should be paid to the backgrounds and views of these appointees, given their prominent roles in managing the CFIUS process. \n \nCoordination With NATO Allies. As it develops its internal approach to CFIUS reviews, the Trump administration may also be the first to need to develop an internationally coordinated approach to national security reviews, as traditional U.S. allies have begun to institute new, more rigorous oversight regimes. In recent years, CFIUS reviews have increasingly involved international cooperation or parallel national security review involving the United States and its NATO allies. Examples include: \n the recent proposed acquisition of Germany\u2019s Aixtron SE by Grand Chip Investment GmbH, ultimately owned by investors in the People\u2019s Republic of China, which was blocked by both U.S. and German authorities;  the recent successful acquisition of Alcatel-Lucent by Nokia Corp., which was cleared by the U.S. and French governments; and  the acquisition of Alcatel-Lucent Enterprise by China Huaxin Post and Telecommunication Economy Development Centre, which was cleared by the U.S. and French governments, as well as by the Chinese government in a simultaneous national security review.  \nIf these multilateral national security reviews become more common, the Trump administration can be expected to face more requests for intelligence sharing and collaboration, and may elect to use those tools to strengthen alliances with close U.S. partners. \n \nRevising CFIUS Authorities. The new Congress also may exercise its authority to refocus the U.S. approach to foreign investment. Members of Congress on both sides of the aisle have shown a renewed interest in reviewing or reforming CFIUS staffing, funding and/or authorities. Topics have included expanding the committee\u2019s jurisdiction to review the economic impacts of foreign investment and requiring the committee to take into account the openness of investors\u2019 home countries to U.S. investment when reviewing specific transactions. At the request of several members of Congress, mostly Republicans, the Government Accountability Office recently announced that it will review CFIUS statutory and administrative authorities. Moreover, to the extent that reciprocal market access is revisited by either the Trump administration or Congress, they may take heed of the recent trend in European national security reviews to take market access and other economic issues into consideration. \n \nThe laws governing CFIUS last underwent a significant overhaul in 2007, and subsequent legislative attempts to expand the mission of CFIUS have been unsuccessful. However, the heightened focus on foreign trade and investment by Congress and the new administration may create a more fertile environment for change. \n \nParties pursuing cross-border investments will need to engage in careful advance planning, including the assessment of relevant national security risks and the potential need to craft a pre-emptive risk mitigation package. Parties should consider a proactive approach to CFIUS in advance of the formal process. \n \nThis memorandum is provided by Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP and its affiliates for educational and informational purposes only and is not intended and should not be construed as legal advice.
